Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2012 09:51AM - edited Feb 28, 2012 02:01PM by LindaLou53 Yorkiemom wrote:  "my question is how did the cancer get to the nodes. My cancer was far from the nodes." Yorkiemom, our lymphatic system is very similar to our blood system in that it covers our entire bodies.  We have hundreds of lymph nodes scattered throughout our body and these nodes are all connected by lymphatic structures similar to veins.  The lymphatic vessels contain lymphatic fluid which is carried throughout our body similar to how blood is carried through our veins. The lymphatic fluid is filtered through our lymph nodes and ultimately emptied into our blood stream where it is excreted through our kidneys. No matter the location of a cancer tumor, there is usually a lymphatic or blood vessel near by.   When a cancer becomes invasive it means it can possibly travel through the body by means of the lymphatic system, the blood system or both.  If a pathology report states no evidence of vascular involvement that typically means there was no evidence of the tumor invading a nearby blood vessel.  If cancer is found in a lymph node, it means the cancer found its way into a lymphatic vessel and was then transported to the lymph node for filtering. The job of the nodes is to filter and remove waste products of the body.  A node positive for cancer was doing its job, trying to filter out those cells.  Breast tissue has more lymphatic structures than blood vessels so we most often see breast cancer spread first to the lymph nodes in the breast area. Anytime a cancer growth has become invasive, there is always the risk of cells spreading to other areas of the body. Fortunately, surgery and radiation can help eliminate cancer in the local area of the tumor.  Chemo and hormonal meds are systemic treatments that can kill off cells possibly already circulating throughout the body.  There are no guarantees that our cancer will not spread, but by treating positive nodes both locally and systemically we certainly improve the odds. Below is a photo of the lymph nodes and vessels in the breast/chest area.  This is part of a poster set I own from the ACOLS (Academy of Lymphatic Studies).  I think it helps when we can really visualize the extent of the lymphatic system in our bodies and realize just what a marvelous system it is in keeping our bodies free from toxic waste products as much as it can.  I hope this helps answer the question of how cancer can spread to the lymph nodes. I am over 6 years out from 23/23 positive nodes after my second BC diagnosis. I continue to be grateful for every day that I remain NED. Live for today...this moment...that is all anyone on this earth has for a certainty.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 10:34AM - edited Mar 1, 2008 02:07PM by LindaLou53 Hi Bobbie, Well it has been 2 years since I first developed the LE and I have only started to row in the last month. My LE was quite problematic from the start and it has taken this long to get it under good control through intensive therapy with multiple modalities. These include CDT, compression garments, flexitouch pump, Kinesio taping, rebounding, and most recently Lebed exercises and cool Laser treatments. In addition I have regularly been seeing a PT for core strengthening exercises and working on increasing range of motion in my shoulders which was impaired from the surgery and radiation. I just this month got the OK to start doing the gentle rowing with minimal resistance on the flywheel. It is actually helping my shoulder issues and I definitely need the cardiovascular workout. My real goal is to hopefully get back to golfing this summer after a 3 year hiatus due to the cancer. With my hand stiffness due to the LE I may need to get larger grips but I'm planning to give it a go this Spring :) Ok, in your case Bobbie since you have not been officially dx'd with LE but are certainly at risk and are having some possible early symptoms, you need to take on any change in exercise slowly and with caution. If you are already doing some forms of exercise, and it sounds like you are, you might start to incorporate brief sessions rowing for like 3-5 min only with the lowest resistance setting on your rower. Make sure you do not try to overdo, it is not necessary to keep up a hard pace, just slow easy strokes so you do not get to the point of breathlessness. After the first day or two, closely monitor your arm for any changes in size or sensation. You may have some generalized body soreness from starting a new exercise, which is normal. Just take it slow, keep up your other exercise routines and continue to work up gradually to a pace that is beneficial without causing any negative impact on your arm. Rowing is really a great exercise on many levels, it helps strengthen leg and shoulder muscles, tuck in your abs while rowing for good core strength and to help protect your back. It is great for aerobic conditioning also. I actually started out rowing this past month for only 2 min sessions just due to my poor aerobic conditioning. I used to participate at the local YMCA in rowing competitions almost 15 years ago. I could row straight for a full hour at a decent stroke/min and often did 10,000 meter sets. So it has been a big bruise to my ego when now I'm huffing and puffing after 5min Lol! But I keep telling myself progress while slow, is still being made... and besides I'm now 15 years older! :) Oh and of course ALWAYS wear your sleeve and glove anytime you exercise!

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 07:49PM - edited Feb 19, 2008 08:02PM by LindaLou53 Hi gb.  Current LE literature and research indicates that once you have been diagnosed with LE it is a lifelong condition.  There are no "cures" at this point in time.  However, it is also true that with early stage LE the visible symptom of swelling may "reverse" or temporarily go away with the use of MLD and elevation.  I hear of some women who can maintain a "normal" appearing arm without wearing daily compression and yet they must still be vigilant in following the full regimen of skin care, protection from injury, avoid repetitive exercises and constrictive jewelry.  The thing to be aware of is that long before there is measurable swelling,  LE has already caused changes in your affected limb's tissue at the extracellular level.  Swelling is actually a late indicator that LE has already taken place.  So your second statement is the more accurate one....you can maintain your LE at a Stage 0 or Stage 1 level, but you will have it for life.  As a side note, I believe that Stage 0 is described as having no measurable swelling, but having symptoms of heaviness, achyness and general sense of discomfort.  Binney correct me if I'm wrong. As to whether or not having scar revision surgery could impact your LE, yes it is possible anytime there is additional disruption to your lymphatic system.   Simple scar revision most likely will not involve removing any additional functional lymph nodes, but it could still disrupt the very fragile lymphatic vessels that lie just below the skin.  Having any kind of surgery causes a temporary inflammatory process in even normal tissue, but inflammation can be particularly problematic with lymphedematous tissue. If you were to decide for the surgery it would be wise to see your physio and have a couple days of good MLD sessions prior to the surgery, wear your compression garments if possible during surgery, and then again be evaluated by your physio soon after surgery to see if further MLD is needed to help counteract the normal inflammation caused by surgery. Does that mean you can never...ever...have any kind of surgery again?  No, but it does mean that any procedure carries some risk with it, most likely small with small surgeries.  You just have to weigh in the balance the benefit of having a surgery that you either need or want.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 08:59PM LindaLou53 wrote: I prefer the KT fingerband to the Transelast because it definitely holds up better to multiple wearings and can be washed. KT also is already in the right size for wrapping and does not have to be folded over first like Transelast does. It is slightly heavier and coarser in texture than the Transelast though so if you have sensitive skin you may prefer the Transelast.  If you find that your fingerwraps irritate the web space between your fingers, wrap a little looser at the base of your fingers or you might try buying a couple pairs of soft cotton white gloves. These can be found at Walgreens for about $4.00 a pair.  Turn the gloves inside out so the seams are on the outside.  Snip the fingertips out so you can check circulation to your finger tips and then wrap your fingerwraps over top the soft glove.  I found it really reduced irritation from the wraps. KT-Medical Finger/Toe Wraps: www.bandagesplus.com/prd/38/73... Wagreens Cotton Gloves: www.walgreens.com/store/catalo...

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 06:16PM LindaLou53 wrote: Thank you so much ladies for all the good comments and support!  I am indeed very grateful to be where I am today.  The older I get the more I recognize the fragility of life and how marvelous a gift it is every day.  SusieMTN - I achieved most of my weight loss by substituting one meal a day for my homemade garden vegetable soup recipe.  I had heard of the Weight Watchers soup and decided to make my own.  I am someone who can eat the same meal everyday for weeks on end if it is something I really like and I have always been a huge soup fan!  A nice piece of crusty hot bread with a little butter and I can get satisfyingly full on a soup meal with very few calories.  In addition I started using a free app on my iPod called "Lose It"  which is a wonderful program to help me track my food intake, calories, exercise and set weight loss goals etc.  Once I started really paying attention to what I was putting into my mouth I realized how many poor choices I had been making without even thinking about it before.  I have changed many bad habits but I am still a believer of "all things in moderation".  I refuse to totally deny myself anything I really love. I drink water exclusively,  use olive oil in my cooking, good fresh fruits and vegetables, no artificial sweeteners, I do use real sugar or honey as sweetners but limit the processed foods and excessive sugary snacks.  I still have my chocolate fix every day, but just in controlled amounts and eating the healthier foods first. Here is my Garden Vegetable Soup Recipe if anyone would like to give it a try!

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 02:04PM - edited Feb 29, 2008 02:05PM by LindaLou53 Hi Debelm, My first question would be how old is your sleeve? If your sleeve is more than 6 months old, they will lose some of their elasticity after many washings and slippage may start occurring more frequently. Also if your arm is improving with treatment and there has been an actual reduction in size, that could also account for the loose top. But if your sleeve would not stay up from the moment you got it new, that is another issue. If your sleeve is a non-custom, off the shelf type which uses your therapist's measurements to find the proper size range you fit in, it could be your arm is just too small at the top for the size range you are in. While a custom sleeve may cost a little more, it will be made to your specific arm measurements at all points and I think you will find it much more comfortable and effective to wear. I have seen the sleeves with a torso strap and I would think that would be just another aggravation, but I have never worn one so can't speak from personal experience. I do wear custom fit sleeves with a 3/4 silicone bead top that always stays up on my arm. The 1/4 area without the silicone goes under the arm near the tender axilla and is more comfortable for me than the full silicone tops. I stay fairly active, use a rowing machine and bounce on a rebounder without any slippage of my sleeve. I would suggest you try a couple of things. First, have your sleeve replaced if it is more than 6 months old if you can swing it financially or with insurance. Consider trying a different type of sleeve, maybe one with a silicone top just to judge the difference for yourself. I will always recommend a custom fit sleeve over one that is designed to fit arms within a similar range of sizes. While non-custom may fit some points just right on your arm, it could be less than ideal at other points, resulting in a loose fit that allows the LE to increase, or too tight in some areas that can cause redness and discomfort. I can honestly say that even though I wear a Class 3 Jobst custom Elvarex, which is one of the thickest and most compressive sleeves you can find, I can wear mine for 16+ hours a day and not experience discomfort or sagging tops. I replace mine every 6 months and having accurate measurements from an experienced therapist will also ensure a good, comfortable fit. Hope you can can find a solution that works for you!
Posts.Title: #@%&*ing Sleeve! BoxerMom987 sccruiser

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 11:58PM LindaLou53 wrote: Erick, Well since water provides compression the deeper you go I suspect that scuba diving would certainly provide adequate pressure to keep your wife's limb from enlarging, but it may be more a question of the impact of her other activities while in the water. Generally speaking any kind of water therapy is great for lymphedema, but especially when the body is totally immersed and benefits from the compression water provides. Some rigorous movements and physical exertion though, may have a negative impact if it really increases the circulation and lymphatic flow. I would think if you and your wife are both experienced scuba divers and this is an activity she is accustomed to, just take it slow to begin with. Keep the excursions brief and slow swimming until she can determine what impact if any it has on her LE. It certainly sounds like a great way to have fun, some good exercise and very likely could even benefit her LE when done cautiously to start. Let us know how it works out for her!

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote:  Hello All!   I know I have certainly been scarce on these forums this last year but that is because Life is busier than ever and I continue to get involved in new activities and adventures! I had my annual scans and bloodwork last month.  Scans again came back NED!  Bloodwork all normal except for a Ca27:29 tumor marker that was 1 pt over the high normal range. While it was my highest result for that test yet, I knew from past discussions and readings here that most tumor markers are unreliable and certainly a few points difference were not significant.  I was not concerned at all and my original onc would never have even made mention of it, but my new onc did request I get it re-checked a month later.  I did the re-check yesterday and my numbers dropped 11 points, well into the normal range! SO...as far as I know I remain cancer free 12 years out from my first dx and almost 7 years out (in Nov) from my very locally advanced second dx! I stopped taking the IV Zometa last July 2011 after 5 years of infusions.  I remain on Aromasin daily and will for the indefinite future since I tolerate it so well.  I  passed 6 years on Aromasin this past May. There have been a few significant changes in my cancer world this last year.  My beloved onc who started treating me in 2000 with my first BC dx informed her patients late last year that she was making a career change.  She moved out of our area, back to the East Coast to immerse herself into research and professorship at an area university, while she also spends time with her aging father.  I really felt like someone pulled the rug out from under me when I got the news, since I credit my onc with making innovative and leading edge decisions regarding my treatment modalities. She was always unafraid to think out of the box and was so well read on the latest research data that I believe she is a big reason why I am still here today. Nothing stays the same however, so I found myself shopping for a new onc late last Fall.  I first went to the "Big Name" onc for an initial appointment, but knew immediately that my personality and his approach to medicine were not going to get along.  I have no doubt he is an expert in his field, but he is definitely "old school".  When I told him my desire was to monitor my status with annual scans and bloodwork and I hoped he was willing to trial me on Metformin, he immediately let me know he was not in agreement and it was his way or no way. Even with my degree of nodal involvement, he wanted no blood work at all, no scans and only would run diagnostics when I "presented with symptoms".  He was nice enough, but I need to know I am a part of the team making treatment decisions for myself and not just the object of the discussion. I know this is an ongoing debate about whether to closely monitor or wait for problems to develop, but I have long been in the camp that detecting and treating early is so much better than waiting til disease has spread enough to create symptoms.  I know of expert oncs and radiologists who totally disagree with the old aproach of "what you don't know won't hurt you....why worry til you have to?" attitude. So I reached out to a few professionals in the cancer world and found myself back at the same practice my original onc worked for.  I am now seeing another onc there who has been in practice for some time.  She is very approachable and flexible in her thinking which I like.  We have already had the Metformin discussion and I have agreed to compromise and wait til the first formal early reports come out from the current trial, which may be later this year. She already ran the Hemoglobin AC1 test on me and while pre-diabetic results are considered 5.7% - 6.4% my result was 5.4% and I have a family history, so maybe I can push for diabetes prevention. I am planning, though to discuss the Metformin issue with my PMD later this week also.  I know that the practice my new onc works for is a participant in the clinical trial of Metformin. While I do not meet the criteria to participate in the trial myself, it is possible my onc has her hands tied about prescribing the Metformin to me outside the trial setting. So I am going to explore my options with my PMD and see if he can network with my onc for her approval. I do not want to start off on the wrong foot with my new onc since I believe she will be easy to work with and she is certainly open to any discussion I want to have.  SO...if I have to wait a little longer for more data to be available I will probably do so. I had a little lymphedema event right before Christmas last year and have now developed early stage LE in my right arm in addition to my longstanding Stage 2 LE of the left arm, but it is well under control and I am staying on top of things with my therapists. I continue to work in the local LE community by being assistant moderator of the monthly Lymphedema Support Group I helped start over 5 years ago.  I visit the local PT school as a patient case study for the clinical Lymphedema portion of their curriculum each year. I also assist my therapist when she works as instructor of LE therapist certification courses held in my area.  I am actively involved with several other LE projects both local and national which hopefully will bear fruit soon for the whole LE community! I have also taken up a new hobby....quilting!  I have always liked to sew and used to do a lot of hand crochet and embroidery work, but with the LE any handwork is much more difficult and tiresome to do.  So a good friend introduced me to quilting and I have become somewhat obsessed with the hobby! When I am not running the household, going to meetings or working on my LE projects you will find me in my basement family room which has now been converted to my sewing/quiting studio! I just finished a quilt for my 84 year old father who is still running an active farm in the midwest.  He likes blue and I found fabric with blue chickens and roosters I thought would be perfect for him!  Here is a look at my latest project:   I also made a wall hanging quilt that taught me alot about adding applique and stitch details to my quilts: So I guess the bottom line of all this random chatting is.....I am doing FINE!  Staying very busy...enjoying new hobbies and so very GLAD and GRATEFUL that I am still here and able to count my blessings every day! So as I like to do at least once a year, I want all the newly diagnosed ladies to take heart!  Fight Hard! I know there are lots of dark moments and doubts about the future during your early diagnosis and treatment phase, but there really is a LIGHT at the end of the tunnel!  You will get done with treatments, your body will start to recover, and you will find with time that Life takes on a whole new sweetness and joy! Hang in there!  You can do it!!   Life is not measured by how many breaths we take...but by the moments that take our breath away! ...I am a 14/9 yr survivor of 2 Primary BCs, 23/23 Positive Nodes (Zometa x 5 years) Started Paloma-3 Clinical Trial 4-14-14 Dx 7/14/2000, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/10/2000 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 8/29/2000 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy 2/25/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 5/9/2001 Dx 11/21/2005, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, 23/23 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 12/4/2005 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 12/22/2005 Taxotere (docetaxel), Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/6/2006 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 4/6/2006 Breast, Lymph nodes Dx 3/21/2014, ILC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 4/13/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Annual Update - LONG ONE...but Still Good News! LindaLou53 NancyD

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2012 03:44PM LindaLou53 wrote: THANK YOU everyone for the good wishes!  I do appreciate each and every one of you, whether you are just starting your treatment journey, or you are years out and still helping others by posting on these forums! I saw my PMD today for my annual visit and he prescribed Metformin without any reservations at all! He feels Metformin has an extremely long and safe track record that should pose no problems, other than the temporary GI upset as my body adjusts. So I plan to contact my Onc and hope to gain her blessing to take the Metformin using the same dosage protocol as the clinical trial.  I'll let you know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 03:58PM LindaLou53 wrote: Otter, your experience sounds like the "Holy Grail" of LE initial evaluations. I am so impressed they even included Bio Impedence measurement which is a relatively new method of early detection in patients not yet showing measurable swelling. I am so happy you posted this because it is encouraging to know that good quality lymphedema care can be found. Hang on to that therapist and be sure to pass the info along to any other friends or patients you know dealing with LE or who are at risk. You might consider followups every 3-6 months with this therapist to again have the bio impedence measurements and limb volume calculations to stay on top of any changes. Particularly if you begin to notice any unusual sensations or discomfort in your at risk limb. Early detection is the key and it seems your therapist is well setup to do that. :)

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 07:00AM - edited Mar 18, 2014 07:03AM by LindaLou53 Hi mnmbeck!   Yes you can wear a compression sleeve and glove/gauntlet for many procedures both surgical and diagnostic where you will be asleep due to either general anesthesia or IV sedation.  I have worn my sleeve and glove while under sedation for colonoscopy and biopsies.  I will be wearing them this week while under general anesthesia for a brief surgery.  The OR staff is well able to maintain the sterile field as needed and also monitor you continuously, so I would not worry about wearing your garments for the exchange procedure. We are cautioned not to wear daytime compression sleeves regularly at night because many sleeves have a tendency to slip or roll down from the top of the arm.  During the daytime we are often tugging or pulling the sleeves back up without hardly thinking about it.  But when we are in a deep sleep if our sleeve rolls down, it can cause increased compression on our arms that will worsen the swelling and could possibly do damage over several hours. If someone routinely has problems with the sleeve slipping down, they should seriously consider being measured for a new sleeve which is a better fit.  But there are other reasons we should not wear our daytime garments for prolonged or night time sleeping. Daytime garment materials and construction work differently than night time garments.  A daytime garment is designed to help control our swelling while our bodies and muscles are in action.  Daytime garments use the constant movement of our muscles to help maintain proper compression and keep our swelling to a minimum during our daily activities.  They do not typically reduce our swelling, they keep it from getting worse. Night time garments are constructed to work best while our bodies and muscles are at rest.  A night time garment, properly fitted, is designed to work better at reducing our swelling overnight.  Only short stretch bandage wrapping at night does a better job of reducing swelling. From a practical viewpoint, however, how many of us take an afternoon nap or fall asleep watching TV while wearing our garments? I certainly do often and suffer no problems, but my sleeves usually tend to stay up. I suppose if someone was scheduled for a lengthy, multi-hour procedure under anesthesia it might make more sense to wear a night time garment? P.S.  And your PS is correct that wearing your garments will be a deterrent from having your LE arm used for IVs, blood draws or blood pressures!  :)
Posts.Title: wear compression garments during surgery? mnmbeck LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 12:30AM - edited Jul 21, 2009 01:51AM by LindaLou53 Lovinmomma, Nanalinda is right....you should ask for a Power Port which will allow for blood draws, chemo infusions and also injecting the dyes for your scans. Dswope, Generally the choice of having a port for chemo is made for one or more of the following reasons: 1. The patient has a low tolerance for needle sticks and feels more comfortable using a port. (the nurses usually prefer it too for convenience) 2.  The patient's veins are fragile or difficult to stick and a port guarantees easy access for infusions and blood draws. 3. The patient has a bilateral risk for lymphedema or another existing medical condition, and is not willing to risk either arm to needle sticks. 4.  The patient's chemo regimen will involve frequent infusions of caustic chemo over a long period of time, which could cause long term damage to the peripheral veins.  The port would protect those arm veins for access if needed in the future when a port is no longer needed. Ports are being used more frequently now than they were when I was first diagnosed in 2000.  Ports have been improved, the power port being an example, providing more functionality.  It still requires special training to access a port though, not every RN or lab tech will be able to do so unless they have been certified. If a patient starting chemo, has good healthy peripheral veins on their unaffected arm and has no particular worry about being stuck with needles, a lot of them choose to get chemo thru the peripheral IVs. Particularly if they are on a chemo schedule of infusions every 21 days vs the more frequent weekly infusions many patients get today. If you poll women who have had ports you will find very many who loved them and would not have wanted to do chemo without them.  You will also find women who hated them and could not wait to get rid of them. Ports certainly have a purpose and in many cases are absolutely necessary, above and beyond the convenience factor for both the patient and the nurses. As with all medical procedures, however, they are not free of risk.  It is a minor surgical procedure to have them placed, there is an ongoing risk of infection and clotting through out the period the port is in place.  They must be protected and maintained with regular flushes. They can be a chronic irritation, depending on their placement, due to chaffing from bra straps and clothing. It boils down to the individual's comfort level, the status of their peripheral veins or other medical conditions that would make using the arms a higher risk than using a port. Lovinmomma, Regarding your question about where to put your IV when you get your new port placed, it really is whatever you feel most comfortable with.  It sounds like your left arm had no nodes removed but would still be considered at risk because you had a bilateral mastectomy.  If you feel more comfortable having the IV in your foot instead of your left arm then be sure to ask for that.  In terms of degree of risk, having a needle stick on an arm without any axillary nodes removed would be less risky than an arm with nodes removed.  Thats not to say it can't happen, because we know of women who have developed lymphedema based on mastectomy alone, no nodal removal. But it is still more a rarity than not. I will say that I have continued to use my right arm for all IV sticks, blood draws and contrast media for the last 3.5 years following my second BC diagnosis. My right arm had 6 nodes removed in 2000 during a SNB for my first cancer, but I never developed lymphdema in it.  When I had a second primary BC in 2005 in the other breast, I had 23 nodes removed and did develop lymphedema in my left arm.  I had to decide whether or not to use my right arm for sticks or have a port.  I chose to use my right arm and so far that has worked for me. I fully recognize that I will always be at risk, but for now it is a risk I am willing to take. I am certainly not trying to change anyones mind about their choice to have a port or use feet/leg veins for their infusions.  This is strictly a statement of my personal choice and what I felt I could best live with. Making difficult decisions has become a way of life for all of us dealing with cancer. Nothing seems to be cut and dried, but always has to be in a gray area of uncertainty. As much as we want to control every aspect of our care and its outcomes, we find that it is just not possible. Still, I strongly feel it is worth the effort and energy it takes to be as educated and informed as possible, to be proactive in our thinking and take as many precautions as seem proven and reasonable to us. Best wishes to you Lovinmomma for your new port placement next week.  Remember, there are NO stupid questions.....but any question runs the risk of getting a very long winded answer like mine!  So be forewarned!

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 11:15AM LindaLou53 wrote: Dswope, The secret is to not come off as a demanding, "difficult" patient. It is very important that we build sincere and honest relationships with our long term medical staff.  As long as you express your LE concerns to the nurses and let them know that you count on them to be your best advocates, you will find that most nurses will be more than happy to take the extra little steps required to safeguard your arm.  Be sure to express your appreciation often and sincerely, and even the occasional "sweet treat" gift to the chemo staff never hurts!  Chocolate can work wonders to motivate and bring happy smiles!

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 02:40PM LindaLou53 wrote: Dswope, At my cancer center the chemo nurses draw the blood and start the IVs at the same time so it has never been a problem.  Practice will differ between medical centers and clinics, but I would certainly discuss with your doctor and the oncology nurse the fact that you are at risk for LE bilaterally and reducing the number of sticks will reduce your risk at each visit.  And yes if it were me, and I knew the nurse would have to start my IV anyway, I would ask that they hold off drawing the bloodwork until the nurse DID have the time to do both.  Most chemo centers will have the IV already inserted and a NS drip running as they wait to get the immediate bloodwork results that might determine if chemo will be held or not. If the bloodwork comes back ok (they are usually checking the WBC) they go ahead and hang the chemo.  If the chemo will not be given based on bloodwork, they would have to remove the IV but at least it was still one stick and blood was drawn instead of having 2 sticks and still not get your chemo. The other issue is that for any patient having weekly chemo and blood draws, 2 sticks each week is using up twice the veins and increasing the chances of having problems finding good veins the next week. Protecting our natural resources applies to our bodies just like it does to Mother Earth!  Lets not be wasteful with our veins when we have a limited supply available.
Posts.Title: I feel stupid for even asking this lovinmomma LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 03:47PM LindaLou53 wrote: Dswope, Definitely speak with your onc about it and see if she feels a port would be beneficial to you considering you have had nodes removed on both sides. I certainly do not want to discourage anyone from having a port who is at risk for LE and will reiterate that my choice was made with the full knowledge that there would be a risk in using my arm veins.  If you do choose to continue having your chemo thru peripheral IVs there are a few precautionary measures you can take that may decrease your risk of complications. Definitely hydrate yourself well the day before, during and after your chemo.  Keep your arms covered up and in warm clothing if in Winter or cold air conditioned rooms. Use a warm washcloth or warm packs if necessary to help pop out the veins in your arm before they start the IV. Make sure the chemo nurses are aware of your LE risk with nodes removed on both sides.  Advise them that you prefer they use the smallest gauge needle possible for your particular type of chemo.  Do not allow them to keep the plastic compression tourniquet around your arm for any extended length of time.  If they are checking all over your arm, hunting for veins, they will have to do it before applying the tourniquet.  Sometimes a nurse may leave the tourniquet in place as they run back for supplies or get distracted by a conversation with another co-worker, do NOT allow this.  I happen to believe that the compression produced by regular blood pressure cuffs and blood work tourniquets presents a higher risk to our LE than a sterile needle stick. My chemo center uses the small wrist BP cuffs and I have one of my own that I carry with me to any other doctor appointments. Obviously the nurse should be wearing gloves, have cleansed your skin before the stick and practice good sterile technique. These are not usually issues in a chemo center but you never know when someone new is in training or just having a busy day so takes shortcuts. It should also be the case than any bloodwork you need is drawn from the same stick they made for the IV.  If you are getting stuck twice, once for blood and once for the IV that is something that should be questioned. If the nurse appears to have any trouble finding the vein once she has inserted the IV catheter needle, don't allow a lot of digging and jabbing at your arm. I have had excellent chemo nurses work on me but they still have a policy that if they can't hit the vein in 2 sticks they stop trying and get someone else to try. Once you get to know your nurses and they get to know your arm, it is sometimes better to have the same 1 or 2 nurses always stick you for consistent success. While your chemo is infusing, the nurses will check on you when they can, but you can also monitor your arm more frequently than they can for any signs that there may be problems developing at the IV site. Sometimes veins will blow or just not flow smoothly depending on positioning and size of the vein.  Its not uncommon to have a little sensitivity at the site during infusion or even a small amount of slight redness, but if you notice obvious pain, increasing swelling, leaking or redness at the site, alert your nurses immediately. Generally speaking, chemo nurses are experts at starting infusions and well experienced at troubleshooting IV problems.  It never hurts though to be an extra pair of eyes in a busy chemo center when they need to know something is wrong. After the chemo infusion is done and the needle catheter is removed, make sure a proper bandage or bandaid is placed and pressure applied to the site. If the needle stick is not bleeding when the catheter is removed you might ask to have triple antibiotic ointment applied before they place the dressing, but often the nurse has the needle out and bandage on so fast you don't have time to do it then.  I often wait til I get to the car or home to remove their bandage, apply my antibiotic ointment and then place my own bandaid.  Make sure enough time has passed and there is no more active bleeding on the original bandage before you remove it however.  Your hands should be clean also when dressing a fresh stick. This may all seem very OCD and anxiety producing, but in reality it is just a matter of being tuned in to ways to help make your infusion experience go more smoothly and help reduce your risk of LE at the same time. (sorry... long winded again)

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 09:21AM LindaLou53 wrote: I completed my 3 years of Zometa last July 2009.  I do not have osteoporosis or osteopenia.  I do not have early stage BC. I do have Stage IIIC locally advanced disease.  My oncologist placed me on Zometa immediately following the completion of my chemo and radiation in 2006 because she was aware of the early study data showing promising results in preventing mets to the bone.  At that time Zometa was typically only given to women with stage IV bone mets and was given on a monthly infusion basis.  We were concerned about the risk of ONJ and I was not comfortable taking the Zometa monthly, so we initially agreed upon every 3 months. I had 6 doses over the first 18 months and then in early 2008 we decided to switch to every 6 months based on further study data becoming available.  I had an additional 3 doses over the next 18 months for 9 doses total by July 2009. I will be seeing my oncologist next Monday for my 6 month checkup, CXR and tumor markers.  Unless she has new information, we are planning to continue the Zometa on an annual basis and I will receive my 10th dose this coming July.  Neither of us were comfortable going off the Zometa completely given my nodal count, but I am also hopeful that more detailed research will give us answers to the questions about continued benefit, drug half-life and ONJ risk with long term usage.  I plan on picking my onc's brain on this issue Monday so I will let you know if there is any new data regarding staying on Zometa for longer than 3 years.
Posts.Title: 3 yrs of Zometa.....Then What? lexislove lexislove

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 09:34PM LindaLou53 wrote: Trobi, There is no cure for lymphedema. There is also no proven long term benefit of surgery for lymphedema. Only in the most severe cases of chronic Stage IV lymphedema would surgery be considered as a last resort. Maybe one day there will be new clinical studies that can document a valid role for surgery in the treatment of non-life threatening lymphedema, but that is currently not the case. Please make sure you have exhausted all other treatments which are the gold standard for lymphedema care. Surgery is not a "cure" or easy fix at all. There is great risk for complications and no guarantee the lymphedema will be better. Please go to see a certified lymphedema therapist with experience to evaluate your current lymphedema status. Ongoing lymphedema maintenance with CDT, MLD, bandaging, compression garments, skin care and exercise can be frustrating and overwhelming at times, but unfortunately there is no magic bullet... surgery or otherwise that can totally reverse lymphedema.
Posts.Title: lymphoveiniuosbypass trobi NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2010 11:34PM - edited Jan 18, 2010 11:36PM by LindaLou53 Update as requested:  I saw my onc today for my 6 month checkup.  I asked her if there had been any new research to indicate whether extending zometa infusions for longer than 3 years was advised or discouraged.  She said there was no research data specific to women without mets who took Zometa for longer than 3 years to prevent a recurrence.  Since I completed 3 years (9 doses) last July, she is still advising me to take a single Zometa dose once a year until further data becomes available. It really is not so much a factor of how many years on Zometa as it is how many doses and how frequent the dosing intervals are.  Women who take Zometa solely for preventing a recurrence or to reverse osteoporosis generally only take infusions twice a year. Whereas women who have Stage IV bone mets generally have infusions every 4 weeks, sometimes for many years. The incidence of side effects seems to be more prevalent in women with frequent intervals and long term (many years) dosing. I asked her which side effects I should be most concerned about.  She stated that renal issues are really not a worry if there has not been a prior history of renal disease and blood creatinine levels and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) are normal.  She said the biggest concern with Zometa is the change it causes in the bone's ability to heal itself.  No one knows for sure just how long Zometa continues to affect the bone's normal ability to generate new bone growth.  They do know it appears to continue to affect the bones for years, even after the Zometa has been stopped.  She said that anyone taking Zometa should avoid any tooth extractions, dental implants or surgery on the jawbone.  Routine cleanings, fillings, crowns and root canals do not pose a problem as long at the tooth root and jawbone is not disturbed. So I will get my next Zometa infusion this July.  I always get dental cleanings and checkups every 6 months.  I have had fillings and broken teeth that needed crowns during the time I have been on Zometa and have not had any problems.  I will be scheduling the replacement of several very old silver amalgam fillings over the next couple of years and will plan to do them 10-12 months after my Zometa infusions if that helps at all.   I have not had a bone density test since before starting Zometa in 2006.  Even though I have been on Aromasin for almost 4 years and it is known to decrease bone density, my onc says that the Zometa will have totally counteracted any affect the Aromasin might have had on my bones.  She feels there is no need to do a bone density test now that I have been on Zometa. My CXR, blood and tumor marker test results should be available in a few days.  I have every reason to believe that I continue to be NED now 4 years and 1 month out from my Stage 3C dx with 23/23 positive nodes.  My onc says I am her "big success story!" and I want to keep it that way! P.S.  my onc also mentioned that new research is showing there may be a possible relationship between high blood insulin levels and cancer growth.  It seems that not only do some tumors respond to the presence of hormones in the body, but that high levels of insulin may also "feed"  tumor growth much the same as hormones do in ER/PR + tumors. She said that some discussion is being given to putting cancer patients who have high insulin levels on a diabetic medication called "Metformin"  also known as Glucophage.  They believe that Metformin may have an anti-tumor  affect and could become a drug used for prevention of cancer. Here is a link to info on a new European study that is forming to look at this issue: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote: I want to post the link to the new survey page for lymphedema therapists on the American Lymphedema Framework Project (ALFP) website.  This is a very important project and I am hoping that you as a patient can send the link by email or in person to your personal LE therapist and ask them to continue to spread the word.  The deadline for completion of the therapist survey is November 20th. The more participants, the more accurate a picture the data will provide of the current spectrum of LE practice.  So...let us as patients do our job in encouraging all therapists we know to participate! Lymphedema Therapist Survey This survey was developed under the leadership of the ALFP research committee chaired by Dr. Electra Paskett and co-chaired by Dr. Mei Fu with input by expert clinicians on the ALFP steering committee. The answers you provide on the survey will be used for research purposes only and are strictly anonymous. Your answers will be evaluated for statistical purposes only. Your input will assist the ALFP in understanding current practices of lymphedema care in the United States today, and will move forward the ALFP goals of evaluating appropriate health care services and improving quality of care for patients with lymphedema. As a practicing lymphedema therapist, your participation is valuable in this worthwhile endeavor. ALFP Therapist Survey Here is the actual link to copy/paste in an email to your therapists: http://www.alfp.org/index.php?pid=survey OR they can just go to the ALFP home page at:  http://www.alfp.org and click on the "Therapist Survey" tab on the left side of the page. If it is easier, just copy/paste my entire post into an email and send to your therapist! Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 09:35PM LindaLou53 wrote: Unfortunately, for anyone who plans on getting their flu shot at the local Walgreens, Walmart, or Target flu stations their policy does not apparently allow them to give flu shots in the thigh.  I have spoken with many of the walk-in store type flu stations and have been told that they are not setup or trained to give shots in the thigh.  Now, granted this information was based on the original, standard flu injection which is intramuscular (IM).  Most of these types of walk-in sites do not have a privacy setting for dropping your pants either, although when I asked our local Walgreens that has a Take Care Clinic with an exam room, they still would not provide a flu shot in the thigh.  The first year the H1N1 flu shot came out, I went to the County Public Health office when they were giving free flu shots.  I wore appropriately baggy pants with a long top and they were willing to inject my thigh while in the midst of a assembly line of people getting their shots.  My PMD's office has since setup their own seasonal Flu clinic available to their patients which does have privacy available as needed.  I think there needs to be more awareness, training and accommodations made by immunization centers for people who require alternate injection sites. P.S. Binney, several Flu Vaccination centers are still using the standard Fluzone injections or offer all versions.  My husband just got his shot today at his employer and they are not using the Intradermal version.  I guess a person could call ahead to find out what is available. I don't know if the plan is to eventually phase out the IM injections or not.  The current intradermal is only available for age 18-64.  As vlnrph mentions above, there is a high dose intradermal version available for those 65 and older.  I suspect I will continue to get the intradermal in my thigh, especially since it eliminates the issues I have run into in the past where the proper size needle or technique for a safe IM injection was not always practiced. My primary reason for posting was to warn anyone considering using an "at risk" limb, that the increased degree of local inflammation with the intradermal flu shot could be a problem.

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2012 05:46PM - edited Oct 22, 2012 05:46PM by LindaLou53 Thanks Vlnrph!  I didn't realize the High Dose vaccine was IM, but that works for me too.  I have a few years to go before hitting 65 though .  I did find it interesting in a CDC article I just found that neither the CDC or ACIP are currently stating a preference as to which vaccine a person chooses to get.  Apparently, clinical studies have shown that the High Dose causes a greater immune response than the standard Fluzone, but they don't know if a greater immune response results in greater protection against influenza disease.  There is a study going on now to test effectiveness, which should complete sometime 2014-2015.  Here is the link to the full CDC article on the High Dose Flu Vaccine: http://www.cdc.gov/flu/protect/vaccine/qa_fluzone.htm

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 07:59AM - edited Oct 11, 2012 08:01AM by LindaLou53 I have been getting a Flu shot for more than 25 years and since developing LE in 2006, I always get the shot in my thigh.  Today I got the new Intradermal Flu vaccine for the first time.  I was informed by the nurse that there would be more local symptoms than the standard flu shot, the amount of vaccine is less (0.01ml vs 0.05ml) and the needle is very tiny (90% smaller than standard vaccine needle) but the intradermal vaccine has approximately the same effectiveness as the standard method. I did experience stinging when the vaccine was injected and an immediate "wheal" or small swollen nodule developed, very similar to the swelling seen from a PPD (TB) skin test.  The area quickly became reddened and itchy which the nurse had said was typical.  The itchyness went away after about 15 minutes but the redness and induration has persisted.  This morning I have an approx 2 inch diameter reddened, indurated area on my upper thigh.  It is not painful, but is warm to touch and a definite area of mild inflammation. I mention this only to warn other persons with "at risk" limbs that the inflammatory process with the intradermal shots appears to be much higher than the standard flu shot.  I would definitely not allow anyone to use an "at risk" limb for the injection.  After looking at the detailed literature from the Fluzone website I found the following table comparing adverse reactions between the new Intradermal injection and the standard Fluzone injection for adults aged 18-64:  As you can see there are significantly more local inflammatory reactions with the Intradermal than the standard Fluzone injection.  I think persons who truly hate needles might prefer the intradermal method, but in the long run you may be dealing with more local discomfort anyway.  I especially think that no flu injection should ever be given in an at risk LE limb, and the intradermal injection may be an even a higher LE risk than the standard. The one "good" thing about the intradermal is there are many locations it can be given since it does not involve concerns about avoiding deep blood vessels or nerves as the Intramuscular injections do.  Any area of the skin on a non-involved or non-at risk limb should be useable for the intradermal injection even though current literature refers only to the upper arm area.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 02:35PM LindaLou53 wrote: "Is my arm supposed to look like a road map when I take off the sleeve? Should I be seeing deep and reddened grooves CAUSED by the sleeve?"  Hi Diane, Well my response to your questions would be "yes" your arm may very well look like a roadmap after removing your night time garment and "no" you should not be seeing "DEEP" or "REDDENED" grooves.  The purpose of night time wrapping, whether it is using short stretch bandages or garments like the Reid Sleeve or JoviPak etc., is to reduce the fluid volume of the arm overnight.  Then the daytime sleeves and gloves are designed to "maintain" the volume of the arm throughout the day but are not intended to do further reduction.  Because lymphedema is the presence of lymphatic fluid in the extracellular tissues, it follows logic that compressing the extracellular tissue will displace the fluid.  The goal of "PROPER" compression garments is to provide a gradient pressure that will direct that displaced fluid into the proper direction for drainage at the larger drain sites in the body.  The degree to which your arm looks like a "road map" will be a variable of the amount of lymph fluid your body produces, the viscosity or thickness of that lymph fluid, the distance that fluid has to travel before it can be properly drained into the larger venous system and also the proper or improper fit of your night time garment will impact the movement of fluid. I wear a Jovipak night time sleeve which has long channels of chipped foam for compression.  Every morning when I take my sleeve off you can see where the wide channels of chipped foam have compressed and pushed the fluid to the path of least resistance which is the small narrow seams stitched between the channels of compression foam.  So every morning my arm has long thin but firm areas of lymph fluid visible in a pattern which reflects the pattern of the night time garment.   My LE is stage 2 and the fluid is very thick and viscous so it does not move out of the arm easily without more massage and other alt therapies. (I use a rebounder, cool laser, Kinesio Tape etc.) I also had total axillary disection so my fluid must move to the neck, groin or belly to drain fully. I only know what my personal experience is with my type of LE, but I would think that women with stage 1, very fluid LE might well see their arm look almost normal every morning if the use of compression and elevation effectively move the fluid completely out during the night.  One thing I have learned is that there are as many different variations in LE as there are people who have LE.  Some manage to get by, wearing just a sleeve, not a glove and do not have problems with hand swelling.  Others, like myself, would have major hand swelling if I never wore a glove. Some can just elevate their arm and gravity alone can move the fluid out, but that is not the case for everyone.  I would think having a "roadmap" on your arm is pretty standard for alot of women, but it may also be an indication that you need to be a little more proactive in other ways for keeping the fluid moving.  I typically spend at least 10-15 min in the shower every morning doing my massage gently moving the fluid.  I make sure I  massage the neck and groin area first, take lots of deep belly breaths, massage down my sides from axilla to groin and then work on moving fluid up my arm to the shoulder and neck area.  I then always towel dry in the proper direction.  My "roadmap" is usually gone by then.  Regarding your question about very DEEP grooves and REDNESS, I would always be worried that your garment is not fitting properly if you truly have deep, painful red marks. Certainly, any constriction that causes pain, numbnes, blanching in your arm is not working as intended and needs to be followed up with your fitter or therapist.  Trying to get a true gradient pressure with bandages and garments is an art and so you do need to monitor your arm for signs that the garment you wear is not performing its job. Hope this helps!  And I want to thank the person who posted the link for the LE Self Care Classes online.  I know Joanne the spokesperson, she is the owner/developer of the JoviPak garments and has dedicated her life to LE education since developing LE herself.  I have met her at various LE conferences and she is truly dedicated to getting the word out about LE.  I have not had a chance yet to listen to her online classes but plan to do so.  Bear in mind that there will always be some variability in the content of classes on LE.  There are many schools of thought on the physiology and function of the lymphatic system as ongoing research reveals more data.  But I do believe that gaining a basic understanding of the body, the lymphatic system and how Lymphedema affects the delicate balance of multiple systems is certainly a big  component of our being able to  manage our own LE more efficiently and competently.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 11:37PM - edited Aug 14, 2008 11:39PM by LindaLou53 Hi Liz, Kinesio Tape has been used for years for sports injury and started being used for lymphedema around 1995. It has gained popularity in recent years as more LE therapists see its benefits for their patients. You are right to have a trained therapist show you the proper application technique for LE because it is different from how the tape is used for muscle injury. There are different versions of Kinesio Tape available but the Kineso "Gold" is the original tape best designed specifically for lymphedema use. Application of the tape requires a slight stretch but both anchor ends of the tape should not be stretched in order to prevent shearing on the skin. Persons with delicate skin or sensitivities should test the tape first on a small area of skin. Some individuals may not be able to tolerate the tape or its removal. The tape is designed to stay in place for 3-5 days and is water resistant so can be worn in the shower and when swimming. The mechanism by which Kinesio tape is believed to help lymphedema is by slightly lifting the skin, creating a larger space for lymph fluid to flow, as the action of your muscles causes the tape to gently move the skin similar to MLD. The tape provides a "mini" MLD massage throughout the day as you wear it. I have been using KT for about 2 years now off and on and find it to be very effective. In particular on my hand and the swelling down my side, the tape would help to reduce the puffiness. I could wear the tape for 5-7 days without problem. It usually was easier to remove the longer I had been wearing it. I would rest my skin for a couple days, making sure it was off anytime I had a professional MLD appointment, and would then reapply a few days later. It is easy to learn how to apply it yourself but you should start out with a therapist showing you the basics. I puschase my KT from Bandages Plus online : http://www.bandagesplus.com/prd/100/1133/Kinesio-Tex-Gold.html P.S.  I enjoy  getting the tape in blue, pink and black for color coordination in addition to the standard beige color

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 11:18PM LindaLou53 wrote: Hope, Levaquin is indeed a very powerful antibiotic with some uncomfortable side effects.  I don't believe it would be considered the drug of choice for cellulitis though.  During my one hospitaliztion for cellulitis I was given IV Ancef for 2 days and then sent home on 10 days of oral Keflex, very similar to katiejane.  I now always carry a filled prescription for 10 days of oral Keflex 500 mg QID (4x daily) just in the event that a cellulitis might start developing while out of town or not close to medical services.  My primary MD renews the prescription every year when I see him for my physical. I will tell you in retrospect I realized that for almost a week before I developed a red, hot spot on my LE arm I had been feeling "tired" and headachy and just "off" which was very unusual for me. I did not associate it with the cellulitis at all until after the fact. Sometimes it takes several days or weeks for a low grade infection to "brew" before it turns into more acute symptoms of redness, heat, pain, fever and chills etc.  Once it reaches that state however, it is a true medical emergency.  Having antibiotics on hand when you first start to recognize the symptoms can often shorten the length and severity of the infection. I was not allowed to wear my sleeve and glove while my arm was still red and hot to touch, but by 48 hours after being on antibiotics that had improved enough I could start wearing compression again.  Hope, I would continue your course of antibiotics until completed and then be sure to have a discussion with your regular onc or whichever doctor you would like to order your prophylactic antibiotics to keep on hand.  Keflex seems to be the most common choice. If your redness and warmth are still present on Monday,  then Levaquin may not be totally effective against whatever bacteria is causing your infection.  Definitely check in with your doctor if not improved. Wishing you a speedy recovery! Linda

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 12:40PM LindaLou53 wrote: Hi Kcshreve, I have been using a wrist BP cuff at home and in the doctors offices for almost 5 years now.  My chemo center also uses wrist BP cuffs routinely for all BC patients getting chemo.  I personally carry my own wrist cuff to all my doctors appointments and ask them to use it instead of the large upper arm cuffs.   There are very few studies regarding the comparison of upper arm cuffs, to wrist cuffs to leg cuffs for accuracy but I feel the wrist cuffs are an excellent compromise for individuals needing to take daily BPs for hypertension or other health monitoring.  I have read that a wrist BP measurement may be around 5-10 pts higher on the reading than an upper arm cuff. One of the most important factors in buying a wrist BP cuff is to get one that has a positional sensor that will not allow you to take a BP reading until your wrist and arm are in proper placement next to the heart.  No matter what type of cuff you use, a BP reading's accuracy is affected tremendously by the technique used.  Size of the cuff in relation to the size of the limb being measured, proper application of the cuff and in the case of the using a stethoscope to hear the systolic and diastolic on the old sphygmomanometer BP units, (like most physician offices) it also is highly subjective to the BP taker's hearing acuity! The advantage of the digital wrist cuffs is they are simple to self-apply, with the position sensor you are guaranteed consistent accurate placement, and with the digital readout no need for stethoscopes or good hearing. The real secret to meaningful BP readings is being able to record a general pattern of readings that can show the trend for either normal or abnormal pressures.  One BP reading by itself has very little meaning especially when different cuffs or devices are used each time.  Owning your own wrist cuff allow you to track your own trends consistently.   I own the Omron HEM-670 IT which even allows me to connect it to my PC and download all the readings that are stored in memory.  The software program creates graphs and reports you can print out and take to your doctors office to show him the trend on your own equipment....vs the single reading they do in the office that usually involves a quick, improperly taken pressure while the nurse is asking questions and your results end up showing elevation due to the "white coat effect". I do not use the wrist cuff on my LE arm but I do use it on my at risk arm which had 6 nodes removed 10 years ago.  Obviously there is a risk in everything we do and for some they prefer the leg or calf BP measurments in all situations.  I believe the risks involved with a wrist BP cuff are certainly lower than using the standard upper arm cuffs. There is much reduced squeezing on the wrist cuffs and with the digital program it releases the pressure appropriately after the systolic is detected as opposed to many office staff who pump every cuff up to over 200 no matter whether the patient has hypertension or not. Whether or not someone at risk for LE chooses to use a wrist BP cuff is a matter of their personal comfort level and risk tolerance.  The wrist BP cuff has been a workable solution for me but I am not pushing this choice for others, only trying to point out the options available. We each must decide what feels right for us.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 01:45PM LindaLou53 wrote: Everyone is of course different in the way they cope with detailed medical information. The language can be totally overwhelming for the average layperson and even for persons in the medical field with no prior experience dealing with cancer. I think we each know our personalities best.  If we are going to be more worried getting a report we don't understand and misinterpret the results prior to seeing the doctor, then I believe it is best to wait for the discussion with your medical professionals.  That is assuming, of course, you are lucky enough to have a physician who takes the time to thoroughly explain the results and all the available options to your full satisfaction. I know that my coping mechanism is to gain as much knowledge as I can about my medical condition. I want to be able to ask informed questions of my doctors and feel like I am an integral part of my medical team.  Knowing this, I am a big proponent of getting test results whether it be scans, bloodwork or pathology reports prior to the scheduled doctors appointment. I get my CT scan results within 24 hours once they have been entered into the hospital's database system and my doctor has had a chance to review them first.  Her staff then faxes a copy of the report to me routinely.  I usually have my consultation appointment with the doctor a week or so following the scans. When I have bloodwork drawn at the chemo center they can immediately give me the CBC results, the tumor marker and chem profile results are faxed to me a couple days later. Since I see my docs every 3 months, I don't have to wait that long for the lab results. With pathology reports, I always request the preliminary report which is usually available within 24-48 hours following the procedure.  I also get the final report when it is available.  It usually just takes a phone call to the doctor's office to let the staff know you want the reports.  The only reason they may delay sending a copy is if my doctor has not yet seen the results first herself. Given that most hospital based practices are now instantly connected to test results when logged into their database systems, there really is no need to wait for weeks to get results. The other thing I do approx every 2-3 years is go to the Medical Records dept at the hospital where I get all my CT scans, PETs, Dopplers...etc. and have them put all my actual scan images along with the final reports on CD.  This is a great way to archive and store all your major medical tests.  It also comes in handy if you ever want to seek a second opinion and can show up with a CD the doctor can pop into his computer and review right there with you.  Most hospitals now offer this as a free service or for a minimal charge. My anxiety related to my illness is greatly reduced when I feel I have accurate knowledge of what is going on.  While it may be true we have little control over the big picture, I believe the choices we make regarding our treatment plan are best made when we educate ourselves to the best of our ability.This is why sites like BC.org are so valuable. I learned the lingo and how to interpret path reports in large part from articles and posts I read here. I find that there is always someone here with more experience, greater knowledge and insight that I can benefit from. As a general precaution, however, I would always recommend that information you gain from any online support site be verified and confirmed with your doctor or through other reputable online sources.

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2011 07:31AM LindaLou53 wrote: I have been on IV Zometa for 5 years now and discussed the Dec 2010 SABCS zometa study results with my oncologist in January.  She feels trial data should be viewed as additional information that may provide a better understanding of treatment benefit, but one study alone cannot show the whole picture.  Because of the variances between study populations and study methodologies, it can take many years and multiple study results before a full understanding is possible.  She was not overly impressed with the 2010 results and said at the time there were other ongoing studies expected to have more positive findings later this year.  I am still scheduled for my July dose of Zometa.  After 3 years of every 3 - 6 month infusions, I have been on annual doses for the last 2 years.  We will be very interested to hear new study results that may affect whether or not I will continue my annual dose in 2012 or not. I am currently 5.5 years post dx of Stage 3C with 23/23 positive nodes and remain NED to date.  I will get my annual CT scan in July a week prior to my Zometa infusion. I have no way of knowing with absolute certainty what has contributed to my NED status or how long it will last, but I do have confidence in my oncologist's opinion and will continue to follow her recommendations. At this point I believe Zometa provides a measurable benefit particularly to post-menopausal women but may very well prove to have a positive impact on an even wider audience as additional studies results become available.
