Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 06:34PM LindaLou53 wrote: Well the news is good!  Just read this post on BCANS from Elaine, detailing the events and success of their efforts today.  Here is her post: What a day! Today, Carol Waller's petition to the Nova Scotia Government to cover compression garments for those with secondary lymphedema was presented to the Nova Scotia Legislature and met with unprecedented success. The day started with a press conference at 10 AM, which although not too well attended, started the ball rolling. Health Critic Dave Wilson, a former paramedic, was there, underlining how important they thought this issue was. We were introduced by NDP MLA Marilyn More, whose office is downstairs from the BCANS office. We were very fortunate to have been joined by Sandra Carr, a survivor who has lymphedema, wears a sleeve and a glove, and was an eloquent and effective spokesperson about how it is to live with it and how it has affected her life. NDP press secretary Kathryn Morse distributed copies of the press release and media package to those members of the press who didn't come, in time to create a buzz of interest in the issue. By the time Chris d'Entremont, Minister of Health, arrived at the house, the press were primed, and he met with a media scrum. He know there was an issue coming up because I suspect there were a few unnamed people at the press conference who alerted him to it. He issued a statement that you will hear on the news tonight that he is instructing his staff to look into the feasibility of covering the cost of compression garments for those suffering from secondary lymphedema. He said that he understands the importance and effectiveness of compression garments as his mother is a breast cancer survivor and wears a sleeve! In the afternoon we were escorted to the gallery of the legislature by Caroline Read, a researcher for the NDP caucus. Barb Thompson and I were very grateful for the support of fellow survivors, Peggy MacLean, Barbara Lawson and Allison Cunningham who joined us there. Marilyn More tabled the petition which sat wrapped in pink ribbons and tulle on the clerk's table in front of the speaker the whole time we were there. She rose again a little later to introduce us to the legislature. Although it was a bit of a wait, as we sat through motions and procedures, eventually it was question time. Dave Wilson asked one question pertaining to health coverage, then as his supplementary question, asked if the Minister of Health would be prepared to commit to a date for reporting on the findings of his department. Although (not unexpectedly) he wouldn't commit to a date, the minister did assure the speaker that his department will be looking into the matter and will report on their findings in a timely manner. After we left the gallery we were met by a gaggle of reporters from every news outlet in the city and even some national stringers. Paul Withers was there from CBC. CTV was there, probably Global as well. John Gillis from the Herald asked some questions and there were several radio stations represented as well. Sandra Carr had her arm photographed from every angle and she spoke at length about how it affects her. According to the NDP staff members, this is more than they ever dreamed of accomplishing in one day, and were extremely impressed by how effective we were, and how well prepared we were. This would not have been possible if it were not for the efforts of Carol Waller and Rose Bechtel. Carol had the drive to put together the petition and collect the signatures. Working with Rose they developed the information on lymphedema, prepared the letter to the MLA's and wrote Carol's story which gave so freely of her experience. Rose contacted Marilyn More and enlisted her support. They are both to be congratulated and thanked for their dedication. The help of NDP MLA, Marilyn More, Health Critic Dave Wilson, and the two staff from the NDP Caucus, Caroline Read and Kathryn Morse was so willingly and generously given that we scarcely have words to thank them. They were simply wonderful. Sandra Carr was introduced to us by Yvonne MacGregor just last week, and we are so grateful to them both. It was just in the nick of time that she appeared and she was clearly the best person for the job. On the way home tonight, I heard the story on two radio stations, and I fully expect that it will be covered by all the news shows and the Herald in the morning. __________________ Elaine F
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL NOVA SCOTIANS TO SUPPORT LYMPHEDEMA PETITION LindaLou53 DoreenF

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2007 09:21PM - edited Sep 30, 2007 09:27PM by LindaLou53 Harley, Its a little unusual for your hand swelling to get worse overnight and get better during the day if it is really LE.  Its usually just the opposite.  When you sleep at night do you try keeping your affected arm elevated on a pillow or do you possibly lay on that side and arm?  Especially with early stage LE when the fluid is more liquid, most persons notice dramatic improvement after sleeping with the arm elevated.  Try keeping your arm up as much as you can at night and see if you notice any improvement. It is also still possible that the hand swelling might be due to something else.  Sounds like you are only a month out from your surgery and you are currently taking chemo?  You might want to make an appointment with the surgeon or oncologist also to rule out any other vascular/circulation problems. If it is LE your best bet is to make an appointment to see a certified LE therapist and let her evaluate the type of swelling you have.  She can measure both arms for a baseline and give you good info on what treatments would be appropriate for you at this time.  I know you have been considering buying some Swell spots for your hand but without an initial LE evaluation, treatment and proper fitting of garments it may be not as productive as it could be. Good luck.  Let us know how it goes. LindaLou
Posts.Title: I am doing everything they tell me not to do to prevent LE... brando She

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 02:24PM LindaLou53 wrote:  Chris13 wrote: Kinda depressing, tho'...I can never carry grocery bags again, get a manicure, etc. I also have an online business that involves shipping packages 4-6 pounds. Chris, never say never!   We do have to think about many of our actions now before doing them, find alternative, safer methods for doing the things we like to do, but there are very few things that are absolutely contraindicated in persons with LE. Part of the secret is becoming more aware of where the risks lie and having a game plan ready for how you will deal with those risks in advance.  There is no reason you should not be able to carry grocery bags or lift 4-6lb packages if you have taken steps to make that a safe activity.  If you learn to approach any new activity with the mindset of taking baby steps, gradually working up to a level that your body tolerates or that you are able to adequately manage without serious LE repercussions, you will find success in many areas. Our human bodies require a certain level of movement and exercise to stay healthy, maintain good muscle tone and strength.  None of us should have to give up any more strength or flexibility than we already have due to SE's of surgery, radiation, chemo and hormonal meds.  We have to be patient and smart about it, but we can regain much that has been lost.  There have been tons of discussions on this board about LE and exercise.  You will find many of our swell sisters leading extremely active, strong, healthy lives because they know their bodies well, learn to cautiously increase their efforts and proactively take the steps to reduce risk whenever they can. Regarding manicures, the biggest issue there is getting an infection from cross contaminated instruments used between clients.  There are many women who regularly get professional manicures but have purchased their own private set of instruments which they take with them to each manicure session.  Any soaking solutions should be changed out for fresh also in the salon.  I believe that false nails may be ill advised because of the risk of damage to the fragile cuticle area plus the moist environment created under the nail is a perfect breeding ground.  But a good nail trim and polish is certainly possible when done with safety measures in place. Chris, regarding your hands puffing up there could be many issues at play here.  If you experienced hand puffiness before you ever had any surgery or cancer treatments involving your lymph nodes, it was most likely not lymphedema at that time.  For most of us, hot, humid weather increases the capillary blood flow in our bodies and can result in some extra fluid rentention in our extremities.  Also high salt intake in our diets, menstrual cycles and certain medications can result in edema which is the result of extra water in the tissues.  This type of swelling is NOT lymphedema. Any swelling, tight rings etc that occur after a person has had lymph node removal, breast surgery or radiation should at least be suspect for early lymphedema.  Edema from lymphatic fluid is not the same as water edema and must be treated differently. A qualified LE therapist should be consulted for evaluation and measurements if the possibility of LE exists. I am not sure of your surgical history so whether you have a current risk for LE or not I don't know.  With your planned UMX and SNB you will then have a risk for LE but hopefully with the knowledge you are gaining now and risk prevention steps you can take, that risk will be lessened.
Posts.Title: Lymph node in breast = LE risk? Chris13 Chris13

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 12:42AM - edited Jul 4, 2010 12:46AM by LindaLou53  "They have known for years that removing nodes in breast cancer patients --even if they are cancerous--does not extend survival. So removing nodes has no therapeutic value and obsolete staging value." I had a SNB with my first BC dx 10 years ago in which 6 nodes were removed, none of which showed up as positive at the quick pathology check during the procedure.  However, a week later after the immunohistochemistry they found micrometastasis to 2 of the 6 nodes.  My surgeon wanted to schedule me for a full ALND.  My oncologist agreed with me, however, that since I would be getting both chemo and radiation due to the micromets there was no need to do further staging or removal of more nodes.  The treatment plan would not be changed based on an ALND. The SNB had done its job in providing proper staging of my cancer.  That was a decision I have been very happy I made. My BC history has unfortunately allowed me to see the coin from both sides and I would never go so far as to say that removing cancerous nodes does not have any therapeutic value.  With my second BC dx 5 years later (a new primary in the other breast) all the signs were ominous for nodal involvement.  Both breast MRI and PET/CT scans indicated high activity in the axillary area.  I still instructed my surgeon to start with the SNB procedure in the hope that she would not have to go any further. As it turned out every single one of the 23 nodes she ultimately had to remove were fully involved with cancer, to the extent that several had already ruptured (extracapsular extension) and many designated as having tumor loads greater than 5mm. As dismaying as it was to be told all my nodes were positive, I was very glad they were surgically removed.  As far as I was concerned they were 23 tumors requiring removal just as much as the primary tumor in my breast. I will never know what the outcomes might have been had I not had a total ALND.  I realize there is no way I can predict what the future holds either, but I feel very strongly that removing those cancerous nodes has played a role in why I am still here today.  Yes, I have lymphedema as a result, but in my book that is a price worth paying to be NED 5 years later with such a locally advanced cancer. I recognize that there are many varied presentations of BC and agree that there are certainly cases where ALND is not necessary or recommended.  But I do not believe that with our current treatment capabilities we can say nodal removal is never of any value.
Posts.Title: Risk after SNB/ Lillie Shockney gets it wrong kira voraciousreader

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote: I had my annual checkup yesterday with my primary MD who I have been seeing for over 20 years.  He is a great guy, has helped me through many medical challenges but is admittedly clueless on the topic of LE.  I only see him once a year since between my breast surgeon and medical oncologist I see a doctor every 3 months. When I saw my primary doc last year he made the comment "well you're looking good!  Do you still have LE?"  I just laughed, showed him my compression sleeve and glove and said "what do you think?" His comment was "I can't really tell much difference between your arms". Since he was walking out the door and heading to his next patient, I didn't have the time then to explain the finer points of LE presentation but decided to definitely catch him this year. SO....yesterday I went prepared. The visit always starts out with the nurse escorting me to the room after getting my height and weight.  She then always proceeds to take my vital signs.  As soon as she reaches for the full BP cuff I hand her my wrist BP cuff and tell her "we have to use this, I'm at risk for LE in my right arm".  I never have a problem with the nurses regarding taking my BP. Next my doc comes in and we talk in general about how things have been going.  I update him with all my recent blood work, scans and meds from the cancer center. Then I handed him a packet of information on LE and told him I wanted him to add this to his medical/staff educational reference material.  I included several of the recent NLN Lymphlink Articles,  the early detection and treatment interventions for LE, the effects of radiation therapy on patients who are at risk for LE, understanding the genetics of primary LE.  I also gave him copies of all the NLN position papers. I intentionally had removed my sleeve and glove prior to his entering the room, and he noted "so its your left arm with LE right?" I proceeded to point out the numerous landmarks on my arm and hand, had him do comparisons in texture and mobility of the skin, pointed out my areas of fibrosis,  made him check grip strength and range of motion differences between my hands, showed him the side profiles and my "puffy" elbow on the left compared to the well defined bony prominence of the elbow on the right. He was impressed with both the overt and subtle differences which could be clinically noted once you knew what to look for. He asked me about compression pumps since that was basically the only modality he had heard much about! I explained the downside to the old type of compression pumps, told him about the newer MLD based Flexitouch system.  Explained the basic components of MLD and the importance of daily clearing of the nodes in preparation for active drainage. THEN...we hit a wall of sorts.  He wanted to double check my BP because it had been slightly elevated when the nurse took it. ( lets see, I had just walked into the office, hopped up on the exam table and was trying to answer nurse questions while she was taking the BP, never given a chance to sit quietly for 5 min and get a "normal" resting BP)  Anyway, my doc was insisting on using the regular BP cuff because he had no way of knowing if the wrist BP cuff device was "accurate"  I told him my concerns about using a standard cuff, how the strong sustained compression of a cuff could certainly precipitate LE in an at risk arm and how I CERTAINLY did not want LE in my right arm also!  I told him I have used a wrist cuff at every doctors office for the last several years and it was the standard of care in the chemo center. I also told him he should be glad I let them use the wrist cuff and don't insist on using a thigh cuff on my leg instead.  His reply was it was a good thing I didn't insist on a thigh cuff because no one knew how to take BPs properly with them anyway! (keep in mind this was a good natured debate between old friends and was not becoming hostile in any way, but I was letting him know how seriously I take the subject) Finally, he said all he wanted to do was verify in his own mind, with his own eyes, that the wrist cuff readings would be similar to a reading he gets on the brachial artery in my antecubital using a standard cuff. Once he could do that, he would never ask to use a full cuff on my arm again.  I told him if he would promise to not pump the cuff up higher than 140 mmHg and would release the pressure quickly, I would allow him to check it this one time. He did the pressure as requested, I then double checked my pressure with the wrist cuff and the readings were within 2 points of being the same.  He was satisfied and told me he would never ask to use a standard cuff again.  I also decided I am going to gather up all the information I can find on the proper way to do thigh BPs and send it to him and his staff! We had a laugh over it, he thanked me again for all the LE information and clinical demonstrations. He admitted more than once that he and most of his medical peers do not have an understanding of LE at all.  I told him we were trying to change that and appreciated him being open minded to my input. I asked him if I could drop off some comprehensive Lymphedema pamplets for patients, plus leave my business card with contact info for our LE support group and that was fine with him. He wrote my annual prescription for prophylactic antibiotics in the event I start to develop cellulitis and also gave me a script for all the bloodwork he wants drawn.  I take the script to my chemo center for my chemo nurses to draw since they are well familiar with my arm. I will also be combining his blood tests with some other blood draws I have scheduled, so I can reduce the number of sticks. All in all it was a productive session with my primary doc.  I felt like I was talking 100 miles a minute though trying to cover alot of ground in a short period of time.  I warned him not to think I was Manic....    I obviously chose to take some calculated risks with my BP but I feel the payoff in return is keeping the communication pathways open and preserving a good working relationship with my doc. One of the difficult issues with trying to convey concerns about needle sticks and BPs in an at risk limb is there is inadequate research available on the subject.  I find that doctors will pay much more attention when there is legitimate study data showing the direct correlation between certain causes and effects. I think I may just start stopping off at his office from time to time and leaving more informational materials on LE as I find them. Who knows....maybe he will start sharing the info with his peers also.  One doc a a time.........we can do it!   Life is not measured by how many breaths we take...but by the moments that take our breath away! ...I am a 14/9 yr survivor of 2 Primary BCs, 23/23 Positive Nodes (Zometa x 5 years) Started Paloma-3 Clinical Trial 4-14-14 Dx 7/14/2000, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/10/2000 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 8/29/2000 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy 2/25/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 5/9/2001 Dx 11/21/2005, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, 23/23 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 12/4/2005 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 12/22/2005 Taxotere (docetaxel), Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/6/2006 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 4/6/2006 Breast, Lymph nodes Dx 3/21/2014, ILC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 4/13/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 07:11PM LindaLou53 wrote: Hi Kay-Kay, I understand your frustration, believe me!  I wanted to comment on the use of wrist BP cuffs as a risk reduction practice. A wrist BP cuff cannot guarantee we won't get LE just as practicing good skin care, doing gentle exercises and protecting our arms from airline travel by wearing prophylactic compression garments cannot guarantee we won't get LE.  But that is why they are called risk reduction practices. We take all the steps we can do reasonably to push the odds in our favor. I happen to believe the wrist cuff to be a lesser evil than a full upper arm cuff.  Some people feel any BP in the at risk arm at all is too much risk to take and insist on thigh cuff BPs.  You have to do what you feel is the right choice for you. Bilateral mastectomy, bilateral nodal removal, any type of lymphatic system damage can put you at risk for LE.  So yes even though you currently have LE on your left you are also at risk on your right due to the bilateral surgery.  Generally speaking, LE will remain contained within the quadrant that the lymphatic damage has occured in, but if both quadrants have had surgery of the lymphatics the risk is there.  Statistically the risk increases based on the degree of surgery and number of nodes removed, however.  Just didn't want anyone to get the impression that a wrist cuff can "prevent" LE, it is only a risk reduction practice.

I had 23/23 nodes positive with extranodal extension (ruptured nodes) in my axilla when diagnosed Nov 2005.  I just had my 2 year CT scan last week and there is no evidence of disease or metastasis anywhere. Don't lose hope....!

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 11:01AM LindaLou53 wrote: You are right of course Binney that we can't really know whether our at risk arm is experiencing an early stage 0 LE with extracellular changes already taking place.  All the more reason for exercising extra precaution anytime the at risk arm is exposed to potential triggers.  The standard NLN risk prevention precautions certainly apply.  If one does use an at risk arm for IVs, needle sticks or BPs out of informed choice or in a situation of medical necessity, our guard should still not be let down. Good skin care, use of antiseptic and antibiotic ointment, not allowing prolonged compression with blood drawing tourniquets, overinflated BP cuffs, or poorly trained staff to work on us is still paramount.  I spend a great deal of effort coordinating necessary bloodwork between my various doctors so that one stick will accomplish multiple requests for labs.  I also allow my chemo nurses to start my heplock used by the radiology department for all scans requiring contrast media.  These may seem small steps but reducing the frequency of having to use the at risk arm and making sure only the "experts" handle those needs seems a worthwhile effort to me. Binney I am very interested in hearing what news you have regarding bioimpedence results being unreliable.  I am aware that it is not effective in patients with bilateral involvement and also has not yet been formally approved for lower limb tracking.  My former LE therapist who moved to KC (and has recently moved back!) had been working with a surgical center to provide presurgical LE evaluation, education and baseline measurements using the L-Dex bioimpedence unit.  She has been very excited about the program but I am not aware that there may be a reliability factor. That would certainly be a disappointment, but may still be better than nothing for trying to detect early stage LE.  Has there been recent research articles on the subject?

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 04:58AM LindaLou53 wrote: AmyaM I was wondering if you are on any anti-hormonal meds like Tamoxifen, Aromasin, Femara, Arimidex? These drugs can cause an inflammatory response particularly in the hands, resulting in pain, redness, stiffness and swelling. I have been on Aromasin now for almost 2 years, but during the first 6 mos to 1 year my hands were in horrible shape with trigger fingers, pain, stiffness in both my LE hand and my Non-LE hand. Fortunately over time the acute inflammation has gone away but I am still left with stiffness and trigger fingers in my Non-LE hand. It's hard to determine if the stiffness I have in my LE hand is from the LE only or some combination of medication side effect also. I will say that during the time my LE was at its peak of swelling and fibrosis, I did have radiating nerve pain into my hand, thumb and little finger in particular. This was very specific sharp shooting pains that were apparently due to nerve compression from the LE swelling. I am not sure why you are having both hands effected though unless it is something systemic... either an inflammatory response to a medication or possibly arthritis. You say they turn red when the pain gets severe... do they also feel warm to touch at that time? Swelling, pain, redness and warmth of the joints could indicate a rheumatoid type condition. Strictly LE should not affect your Non-LE hand also. Let us know what you find out. :)

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2008 03:08AM - edited Aug 15, 2008 03:13AM by LindaLou53 Thanks for this info Rolniak! I remember reading about reverse mapping last year and will be interested to hear how further study results turn out. It looks like the study is currently following women for 1 year post surgery. I hope they will actually keep track of them longer than that since LE can occur many years later. It may be that they feel any occurence longer than 1 year could possibly be associated with other factors than surgery, however it would be hard to know for sure. Here is a Medscape article about the study:(I have bolded some statistics of interest) New Procedure Eases Lymphedema After Breast Cancer Therapy Allison Gandey Information from Industry March 30, 2007 - A promising new surgical technique appears to spare most women the painful arm swelling that many say is worse than mastectomy. The procedure, dubbed axillary reverse mapping (ARM), was developed to prevent lymphedema caused by faulty drainage of the lymph nodes, one of the most common adverse effects of breast cancer treatment. Senior author Suzanne Klimberg, MD, from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, in Little Rock, says her group is the first to study lymph node drainage in the arm and the procedure they developed has proven so effective it is already being used as standard practice at her center. "The most important implication - and the thing I would like clinicians to take away from this study - is that one can identify and protect the lymph vessels draining the arm," Dr. Klimberg told Medscape. Led by Margaret Thompson, MD, also from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, the group describes their experience in a paper scheduled to be published online in the Annals of Surgical Oncology. The work was funded by the Tenenbaum Breast Cancer Research Foundation and presented earlier this month at the Society of Surgical Oncology 60th Annual Cancer Symposium in Washington. Anywhere from 5% to 50% of women undergoing surgical treatment for breast cancer develop lymphedema - a range that tends to depend on the extent of surgery. "The removal and analysis of the lymph nodes under the arm remains the most important factor in determining the severity of disease in breast cancer patients," Dr. Klimberg explained in a news release. "In the past, surgery to remove the lymph nodes and most of the fat and tissue in the armpit often resulted in complications including lymphedema." To prevent swelling, the new ARM procedure evaluates the ways in which fluid drains through the lymph node system using an injectable blue dye. "Mapping the drainage of the arm decreases the chances of unintended disruption of the lymph node system during surgery and reduces the risk of developing swelling in the arm," Dr. Klimberg noted. More Work to Be Done to Confirm Benefit The surgeons point out in their paper that success of this technique in preventing lymphedema will require ongoing follow-up and studies. "We currently have a prospective study that will measure arm volume. At present, the longest follow-up is 8 months." Of the 40 patients who had surgery for breast cancer in the present analysis, 18 required an axillary lymph node resection. Of these, 14 patients had a sentinel lymph node biopsy with the axillary lymph node resection. The researchers report that none of the patients where the ARM lymphatics were identified and preserved have developed lymphedema. They found that injection anywhere in the arm worked well. The upper, inner areas were chosen simply because they had the most rapid drainage and it also hid the tattoo, which could last anywhere from 1 week to 6 months. "Prior to our use of the ARM technique, we certainly would have sacrificed a good number of these now-easily-identifiable arm lymphatics, not realizing that they were draining the arm and not the breast," they write. "The main critique for our work is the short follow-up and real lack of evidence that it does prevent lymphedema," Dr. Klimberg told Medscape. "The same critique was true of the sentinel lymph node procedure that, after a recent large trial, turned out to have a 7% incidence of lymphedema." She noted, "Our work actually explains those results, as often the arm lymphatics juxtapose or overlay the breast lymphatic but were nonconcordant." She points out that the radioactively hot breast lymphatics were never blue and the blue arm lymphatics were never hot. Dr. Klimberg will soon begin training seminars on the procedure in the United States. The sessions will be sponsored by the global medical device company Ethicon, a branch of Johnson & Johnson. Ann Surg Oncol. 2007. In press. Here is a link to the actual clinical trial going on: http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00572481 I also wonder if the consensus is that by reducing damage or removal to the nodes that drain the arm will you also reduce the frequency of truncal or breast LE? Certainly removal of the nodes draining the breast could still present problems for breast and truncal LE, but preserving the arm draining nodes might lessen the total lymphatic system compromise created by surgery.

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote: I am posting this for my good friends at the BCANS website who are trying to get current policy changed for Lymphedema coverage in Nova Scotia.  Our dear Jinky (Carol) spent many long hours creating the petition and gathering over 1000 signatures.  The petition will be formally presented tomorrow, Nov 6th to the Nova Scotia Legislature.  If you are a Nova Scotia resident, please read the following details provided by Elaine, the administrator of the BCANS website and organization: Lymphedema Petition by Carol (Jinky) A Petition asking the Nova Scotia Department of Health to fund the purchase of compression garments for breast cancer survivors is being presented to the Legislature on Thursday, November 6th. It is expected to be early on the order paper when the house sits at 1 PM. We hope to have a good number of people in the gallery at the time to show support. During question period right after that, Marilyn More, NDP MLA for Dartmouth South will rise and ask questions of Health Minister Chris d'Entremont about why this is not covered by MSI. The petition requesting MSI to cover the cost of lymphedema garments was started by Carol (Jinky) of Truro, who gathered more than 1000 signatures from Nova Scotian breast cancer patients and their friends and families. Unfortunately Carol will not be able to be there because of ill health. However, on her behalf, Breast Cancer Action Nova Scotia, a voice for survivors, is presenting the petition to the government and requesting the Legislative Assembly to change the existing legislation so that the cost of pressure garments for lymphedema treatment is covered by MSI. A press conference will be held at 10AM in the lobby of the legislature, and all are welcome there as well. Breast Cancer Action Nova Scotia will be holding a press conference at the Nova Scotia Legislature Building on Thursday November 6, 2008 at 10am. For far too long breast cancer patients have had to bear the burden both of a life altering condition called lymphedema and the financial cost of treating it. We feel our provincial government should be paying for treatment costs for lymphedema that is secondary to breast cancer treatment. On that day, a petition to cover the costs of compression garments will be presented to the Nova Scotia Legislature. Please join us in the Gallery at the legislature to show our support of this really fundamental issue. Be there for 12:30, no later: Meet at the NDP Caucus office at 1660 Hollis St., 10th floor , one block away from the Legislature. Carolyn Read, NDP Researcher, will take us to the Legislature, get us to the right place and tell us what to expect. See you there! Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 11:27PM LindaLou53 wrote: Hi Lori1964.  You say you are going to a hand therapist for your lymphedema, is she also a certified lymphedema therapist?  Does she do full MLD not just on your arm and hand, but also your neck, back, chest, abdomen, groin and side below your armpit? The lymph fluid must be properly directed all the way down to the major drainage areas and not just partially moved out of the arm. It is not at all unusual for lymphedema fluid to collect not only in the arm but also in the breast and side, called truncal lymphedema. It is possible to have the feeling of puffyness or tenderness in areas where the fluid collects. Other causes for the type of pain you are having could be rib pain from radiation.  Ribs can remain very sore and tender for years after rads and it might be that a buildup of lymphedema fluid aggravates that situation.  I am glad you are seeing your Rad doctor Tuesday and hopefully he will be able to rule out any other possible causes for your pain. If there are no other medical reasons for the discomfort in your side after your hand treatments, I would certainly either discuss the possibility of truncal LE with your therapist or else find a new certified therapist who is more tuned in to proper Lymphedema management.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 04:08PM LindaLou53 wrote: Kam, my longhaired tuxedo Socks was feral born along with her brother Cream Puff.  It took me over 8 months to trap them and get them to the vet so they could be fixed before having babies of their own. I WISH they didn't shed but they do. At least much more than my little shorthaired tabby did. Most of it is their dense undercoat though, which can come out in clumps when they groom.  Very  little of the long outercoat actually sheds. I believe animals definitely can read our emotions and that includes cats. I suppose many of you may have read about the ability of some dogs to "sniff" out cancer or dogs who can sense when their human companion is about to have a seizure. There is no question that animals possess sensory abilities that surpass human's. I had an experience with my little tabby cat Boo Boo which now makes me wonder just what her powers of detection were telling her at the time.  For years Boo Boo would sleep in bed with me and my husband and she had a nightly routine which I thought strange but cute.  She always liked to settle in along my left side in the crook of my arm, but before going to sleep she would spend 2-3 minutes "kneading" my underarm area with her paws.  She did this without fail every night for several years. I was diagnosed with my second breast cancer in 2005 which was on my left side, and had 23 massively positive nodes removed by total axillary dissection.  I spent the first 2 weeks post-op sleeping in a recliner and keeping the cats locked out because of all the drain tubes and fresh surgical site.  But when I did return to the bed, Boo Boo once again came to sleep with me, however, never again did she ever attempt to knead my axilla as she had done prior to the surgery! I know it sounds crazy and of course there is no way to know for sure, but I often wonder if she had detected that something wasn't quite "right" in that area of my body??  Little Boo herself went on to develop cancer 3 years later and even had 6 months of chemo which kept the tumor at bay for awhile. Who's to say for sure just what an animal understands or is capable of sensing?

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 06:10PM LindaLou53 wrote: I have been participating in a LE study by Jane Armer in Columbia Missouri at the Ellis Fischel Cancer Center.  It involves body weight, perometry of both limbs x 3, tape measurement of both limbs x 3 at each 6 month visit.  There is also a lengthy paper survey that must be completed annually involving questions on the physical, emotional, social, financial and quality of life impact of LE.  Jane is also doing a side study called the Genome Wide Association analysis: Post-breast cancer lymphedema.  This is a one time sampling of tissue using a cheek swab for genetic testing. For those of you not familiar with Jane Armer, she is a truly remarkable woman.  Very kind and approachable in person, she gives the first impression of a sweet motherly type, and yet she is a brilliant researcher, travels worldwide to present at professional gatherings, has been published many times over and has received numerous accolades for her dedication to lymphedema research. Dr. Armer is herself a breast cancer survivor and LE patient. Here are a couple interesting links with her personal bio and info on her studys. nursing.missouri.edu/faculty/f... nursing.missouri.edu/research/...  M-Star:  Thanks for posting your videos...it is great to hear the UK is leading the way in baseline measurements and followup care.  Now if the US can just get their act together!

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2010 07:08PM LindaLou53 wrote: Musical, especially with your lymphedema I would consider camisoles with bra pockets instead of a bra, and use a small light weight form.  Tight bra bands around your trunk are not good for lymphedema.  I have LE also and find the camis much more comfortable. Wearing a camisole with a light weight form like the TLC Micro Bead also has the advantage of staying in place because you can tuck the bottom of the camisole inside the waistband of your slacks or skirt.  They don't ride up like a bra does with a light weight form!  I am working now on adapting several of my camis and tank tops to hold the Micro Bead forms.  I'm doing the trial and error method for now but once I get my process refined I will post something with pics.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2012 07:35PM LindaLou53 wrote: I love my furbabies and can't imagine being without pets. I think the concept of an older, more mature pet is very wise and often gives a good home to pets typically overlooked by prospective families.  While I understand the concerns of owning cats when having LE, I hope anyone who truly prefers cats would not rule them out based solely on their LE.  I found all 4 of my pets in 1993. One 6 month old cat was a rescue from a flood in our area, 2 wild kittens were born to a feral mother in the woods behind our house and a beautiful black lab pup I had picked out from a breeders litter.  This was long before I developed LE but my pets have all been long lived and I could never have parted with any of them based on a new dx of LE.  It is just a matter of thinking through your interactions with your pets, reinforcing safe play behavior and taking extra precautions when necessary. My beautiful lab Libby broke her back at the age of 5 and was paralyzed for 3 months before regaining her ability to walk. In her later years her inability to walk returned and for the last 1.5 years of her life I had to lift her in and out of her little red wagon we used to take her for walks thru the neighborhood or make a visit to the vet. This was all after my LE dx and it was a matter of finding the right assistive devices and proper body mechanics for me to safely transport her. Libby weighed 95lbs at her peak and 80lbs before she passed in 2008 just 3 months shy of her 15th birthday.  Libby in her wagon sitting with my husband outdoors enjoying the Fall weather.  While my 3 cats were all over 13 years old when I developed LE and long past the playful biting-attacking stage of kittens, I fully expect to have more cats after my remaining cat passes.  Cream Puff passed at 14 years old from liver failure and Boo Boo at 16 from bladder cancer.  My remaining cat, Socks, just had her 19th birthday and shows signs she may very well make 20 next year. I have not had major concerns about taking care of my cats after my LE dx. I did make sure I practiced good protective skin care, and wore protective garments in the rare situation where one of the cats would be stressed out when transporting to the vet and might display panic behavior.  Cream Puff:  Boo Boo:  Socks (19 and still going):   Aggressive or fear response behavior is possible with almost any type of pet. Attack type play is often a learned behavior, made worse when encouraged.  While there may always be an element of risk for a LE patient who chooses to be a pet owner, that is one thing I refuse to let Cancer and LE take away from me. Crystal, good luck in finding the pet that is right for you and your husband. I hope you have many happy years enjoying the love and affection of your new furbaby!

I am not aware of any studies showing that massaging the arm causes lymphatic regrowth. If you are, please share.  I do know there is current research into achieving regeneration of lymphatic structures in animals that is very encouraging. We also know that properly performed MLD prepares the body to accept the excess fluid which must be moved from the damaged lymphatic area to an area of the body that is still functional and can process that fluid back into the circulatory system.  More to the point of my post however, is we welcome all ideas and input here on this forum, but I have to admit I am a little shocked at your sharp and uncalled for response to Kira's post.  Expressing your feelings that using laymen's terms may be more easily understood is one thing, but the rude overtones of your response immediately damages your credibility as a well-intended contributor to this forum. Is it just a bad day or should we plan on wearing protective gear whenever you post? I'm getting my helmet ready now....just in case!

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote: Hello All, If you or someone in your family has access to one of the following Apple smart devices, you could help provide important feedback on a new FREE Lymphedema mobile app designed to help patients locate trained lymphedema therapists.  Here is a list of devices compatible with the new app: iPhones - 3GS, 4, 4S, 5 iPod Touch - 3rd, 4th and 5th generations iPad - any version You must be running iOS 5.0 or later on your device in order to run the app. The new app is called LOOK4LE and is being developed by the American Lymphedema Framework Project (ALFP) and the University of Missouri Informatics Institute. The app currently has over 900 LANA certified Lymphedema therapists listed and more will be added as therapists opt to add their contact info. The app became publicly available on Sept 10 and is a free download from the iTunes App store. A formal description of the app with print screens and a link to the App Store can be found on the developers website at: http://hydrogensoftware.com/products.php?id=9 The developers wish to reach out to the Lymphedema community for feedback. They would like input regarding any of the following areas: User friendliness Content Completeness Functionality Technical Issues  Additional features desired for new versions I was asked to do a beta review of the app and got permission to also invite our lymphedema community here at BC.org to lend their feedback. There is a brief online survey consisting of 10 questions with the ability to leave comments as you desire.  The survey link is not currently publicly available, but I will provide it to anyone with a compatible device who is willing to complete the survey after testing out the app. Just PM me if you wish to participate in the survey.  For anyone who prefers to use the app but not go through the formal survey process, I would still be interested in hearing your comments and first impressions.  Feel free to PM me with any issues or suggestions and I will see that they get forwarded to the development team. I am always excited to see LE getting attention in any form and being added to the world of digital mobile apps is a good thing.  Let's give the developers honest critique and suggestions for what we would like to see in a "find a LE therapist" mobile application! Thanks for your consideration.  Linda    Life is not measured by how many breaths we take...but by the moments that take our breath away! ...I am a 14/9 yr survivor of 2 Primary BCs, 23/23 Positive Nodes (Zometa x 5 years) Started Paloma-3 Clinical Trial 4-14-14 Dx 7/14/2000, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 2/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 8/10/2000 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 8/29/2000 AC + T (Taxol) Radiation Therapy 2/25/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 5/9/2001 Dx 11/21/2005, ILC, 5cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, 23/23 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 12/4/2005 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 12/22/2005 Taxotere (docetaxel), Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/6/2006 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 4/6/2006 Breast, Lymph nodes Dx 3/21/2014, ILC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 4/13/2014 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: LindaLou53 wrote: Wanted to share my good news in hopes others may be encouraged. Just got results of my Chest/Abd/Pelvic CT that was done yesterday. I am NED! Scans show only the expected effects of surgery and radiation change! For those who don't know, I have Stage IIIC Invasive Lobular Ca which was diagnosed in Nov 2005. (this was my second primary BC diagnosis..had Stage 2A IDC in other breast in 2000) My most recent BC is more locally advanced with all 23 axillary nodes being positive for cancer plus some nodes had already burst in the axilla (extracapsular extension). Thankfully the Tumor was Grade 1 (5/9 with lobular getting an automatic 3 for tubule formation). I was treated with bilateral mastectomies, 6 rounds of Taxotere IV and oral Xeloda, 6 weeks of 3 field radiation including chest, axilla and supraclavicular nodes. Completed chemo and rads June 2006 and have been taking Aromasin daily since April 2006. I also get infusions of Zometa once every 3 months and will continue that for a total of 2 years. I know it is not yet 2 years out from my diagnosis but my oncologist is very happy with these results given my nodal involvement. As you can imagine I am very happy too! We have been doing scans every 6 months but if I get another clean scan in Jan 08 we will go to annual scans. Just wanted to post as an encouragement for others with multiple nodes involved. Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 03:10AM - edited Aug 13, 2010 03:12AM by LindaLou53 Hi Kcshreve, I don't use my LE arm for BPs for a couple of reasons.  One being that I am not sure if the reading would be as accurate on the LE arm.   The wrist cuff measures BP by detecting the arterial pulse in the wrist.  With the increased extracellular fluid caused by LE and swelling in that area I don't know what effect that might have on getting an accurate BP.  I have tried searching for articles on the accuracy of BPs taken on an arm with active lymphedema but have not yet been able to find one.  All articles advise not taking BPs on an arm with lymphedema. The other reason is that I believe the risk of BP causing worsening LE symptoms and possible cellulitis in an arm with active lymphedema is greater than the risk of developing new onset lymphedema in an at risk arm. Because the lymphatic system is divided into quadrants, the risk of cellulits is much greater in the quadrant that is already affected by lymphedema.  The arm with LE already has protein rich lymphatic fluid circulating in the extracellular tissue.  This is why IVs, needle sticks and BPs in an arm with LE are not recommended because any additional trauma, excessive constriction or introduction of bacteria can rapidly develop into increased swelling, inflammation and serious infection.  An at risk arm by definition does not have the protein rich lymph fluid circulating in the extracellular tissues thus is at lower risk than a lymphedema arm for inflammation and infection. Taking a BP in an at risk arm certainly MAY contribute to the development of active lymphedema in that arm, however, there are no studies that we can refer to which will give us solid statistical percentages to define that level of risk.  So much of what we know about lymphedema is anecdotal or presumed risk / causal relationships.  That's not to say this is not valuable information but it is very hard to quantify the degree of risk involved in specific behaviors. My perception is that taking BP in an at risk arm instead of the arm with active LE, is the lesser of two evils.  It would be so much easier to make these types of decisions if there were clinical studies that could clearly point out the highest statistical risks associated with the various BP options but to my knowledge they don't exist. Regarding your upcoming surgery and necessity for having automatic ankle cuff BPs during the procedure I think that is very commonplace in most OR suites.  OR and ER staff are usually very adept at taking BPs in legs and have the appropriate equipment and training to do so safely.  I agree that leg BPs can be very uncomfortable when you are awake and would certainly discuss this with your surgical staff to see what options are available to you. I have found doctors offices to be more open to allowing use of your personal wrist BP cuff than Inpatient or Outpatient surgical centers are. They will generally use only their own equipment but usually are willing to work with you regarding taking leg BPs manually vs automatic or lowering the pressure settings as needed for your comfort level. I use my wrist cuff at home not because I have hypertension but because I actually have low blood pressure and frequent episodes of postural hypotension.  I do not take daily pressures but will check my pressure when I experience symptoms of hypotension and keep a running record for my primary MD. Otherwise I see a doctor of one sort or another every 3 months and take my own cuff with me to those appointments.  At the cancer center I don't have to worry about it since they routinely use the wrist cuffs for all office appointments. Hope this is helpful.  I wish I could give you a sound and fact based answer to your questions but unfortunately all I have is my personal opinion and interpretation of what little I know about lymphedema and physiology.  I have come to terms with the fact that I am unable to be totally protected against all possibilities and thus have to do the best I can making informed decisions.  I prefer not to be overwhelmed worrying about the "what ifs" and am not willing to subject myself to blame for decisions made in good judgement at the time, even if someday those choices have undesireable results.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 12:17AM LindaLou53 wrote: I recently was surprised to be bitten by a mosquito through the double layer of both my compression sleeve and glove while sitting in my own kitchen!  Mosquitos have been bad in our area lately and they are finding their way into the house when we open doors. My first clue was the beginning of an itch underneath my garments in my forearm area.  I didn't realize I had been bitten until I pulled the garments off and saw the inflammatory response created by the bite with a huge welt in the center:  I washed the area with cool water, antibacterial soap, a little alcohol wipe and then applied an ice cube wrapped in a wet wash cloth.  I kept the ice on for about 15-20 min which really helped to take the itching down.  I felt cold would be better at slowing down the histamine response and decreasing the inflammation.  Here is what the bite looked like after 20 min of cold application:   I applied some neosporin ointment and kept my garments off until after my shower an hour later.  This is what the bite looked like after an hour.  The inflammation was almost totally resolved and no more itching!  My experience is that any bite, cut, burn or injury to my LE arm is always more inflammatory or reactive than it would normally be in my non-LE arm.  In this specific instance of a single mosquito bite, I believe the initial redness, swelling, itching etc. to be a result of the histamine response which thankfully is usually of short duration.  I would not start to worry about a mosquito bite unless the redness persisted along with onset of increasing heat and pain.  I suspect our damaged lymph systems may be able to withstand a single bite without too much difficulty, but multiple bites with extensive inflammation to a larger portion of the limb may result in volume increases and sustained flairs of LE, along with increased risk of infection setting in. We still have to always be concerned with ANY break in skin that might allow bacteria to enter, so always clean the area immediately, disinfect with appropriate alcohol type wash and apply an antibiotic ointment.  I really hate not being able to enjoy the warm, summer evenings outside but do try to avoid getting any bites at all.  I will have to give some of the products mentioned here in this thread a try!  I would love to feel more confident visiting my father who lives on a farm in a rural area that is full of ticks, spiders, mosquitos etc...and many of those make their way into the 100+ year old farmhouse.  Hard to explain to other people why I decline camping trips, river rafting, fishing and other outdoor activities which put me a little "too close"  to dear old Mother Nature!

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 12:33PM - edited Sep 8, 2009 05:12AM by LindaLou53 Hi NativeMainer, Thanks for your informative reply!  Its been 31 years since I was in nursing school and I know technology has certainly changed for the better.  We had no automatic BP devices while I was in training, but we were trained to take BPs in the upper arm and thigh.  From the little research I have done recently it seems that getting an accurate BP measurement is dependent on very many variables and is actually the most difficult vital sign measurement to obtain consistent accurate results on. These variables include body positioning, cuff positioning, cuff size, level of cuff in relation to the heart, too rapid deflation of the cuff, the white coat effect, whether or not BP is taken after at least a 5 min rest period and not while asking patient to answer questions at the same time,  taken at least one hour after ingestion of caffeine,  smoking or exercise, and the hearing acuity of the person taking the pressure in the case of manual BP. The informative value of a BP is really more in showing a trend than the actual readings at any given point other than in the case of an extremely high or low systolic or diastolic value. The point you bring up about reports of injury and blood clots related to automatic BP machines is a very pertinent one, especially to the breast cancer community.  Many cancer patients will be on medications which predispose them to blood clots for several years. Unfortunately, I believe for most surgical procedures requiring IV sedation or general anesthesia, automatic BP machines are routinely used.  In the case of women with bilateral nodal involvement who would require thigh or calf BPs during a procedure, this combination makes me very nervous.  The worry about the development or aggravation of existing DVT from a BP cuff on the leg, even a manual cuff is of great concern in my mind. There obviously needs to be a great deal more study on the least harmful and most accurate ways to obtain BP readings. As wonderful as the current level of training in nursing schools is, what I am seeing in actual practice in a variety of health care environments is less than ideal.  I happen to go to an extremely busy chemo center that has at least 20 recliner chairs occupied by chemo patients on any given day.  They utilize wrist BP cuffs primarily for the fact that in most cases the patient will have an "affected" arm which cannot be tested for BP and the other arm which will have an IV line of some sort and is not conducive to using a full upper arm cuff.  There is certainly a percentage of patients like myself there also who will have bilateral involvement, whether it was a prophylactic mastectomy on one side and no nodes removed, or nodal removal on both sides. I have yet to see anyone receive a thigh or calf BP in the setting of the chemo room.  There are 2 rooms in the chemo center that have regular hospital beds.  Usually the sickest or most physically compromised patients use those rooms.  Otherwise there is no ability to have a patient lie flat to obtain a thigh BP (recliners only lean back to a small degree). If you consider the fact that for some IV chemo routines like Adriamycin and Taxol it is necessary to take more than one BP throughout the administration process, that only adds to the issue of how to provide for accurate thigh or calf BPs in a practical sense. I know there will be ongoing debate on this issue and I welcome all points of view and literature sources that can help us truly be informed to make our best decisions.  I have found limited studies on the accuracy of using wrist BP cuffs compared to the standard upper arm cuffs.  The most recent studies, however, indicate that wrist BP cuffs have been found to be as accurate as standard manual sphygmomanometer cuffs and also the digital oscillometric devices.  One feature of a wrist BP cuff which should be absolutely present is a position sensor that will not allow the BP reading to take place until the arm is placed in the correct position at heart level.  This eliminates one of the biggest reasons for inaccurate readings.  Certainly for individuals needing to self monitor their BP at home for already exisitng hypertension, the wrist BP cuffs have become the device of choice. While I have no research to back up my opinion, my gut instinct tells me that the risk of precipitating a DVT with a wrist BP cuff is much less than that of a thigh or calf BP cuff. I choose to avoid leg BP readings primarily for this reason and also because I understand that the current level of expertise in taking accurate and safe leg BP readings is lacking in many of the real world clinical settings. Many drs offices or walk-in clinics don't even have the correct cuff sizes to use and staff have not been trained for a proper thigh BP measurement.  I prefer to have my medication and treatment choices based on an accurate wrist BP reading rather than an inappropriate response to a misunderstood or poorly taken leg BP reading. I also still feel that utiliizing a wrist BP cuff, while not totally eliminating the risk of LE, does significantly lower the risk compared to using standard upper arm cuffs for BP.  I will restate again...this is MY choice...MY understanding of the calculated risk for my developing LE as a result...but it also is a choice that I feel weighs in the balance the multitude of factors that we must consider when attempting to protect our overall health.  As much as we want to avoid LE there are other serious health issues we need to be concerned about preventing also.  Until more comprehensive research data is available as to the actual cause and effect of all these issues, we must make our best personal choice. I certainly don't want to bias or mislead anyone, but I think we need to keep an open perspective on the full spectrum of options available to us.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 05:10PM LindaLou53 wrote: Nagem, You can try Jo-Ann Fabrics or Hancock Fabrics online to order your microbeads and have them shipped to your door if that is easier.  They are on sale now at Jo-Anns for $14.01+ Shipping and Sales tax.  Just do a search on their website for Poly-Fil Micro Beads.  The only problem is that it is a HUGE bag of microbeads and will be much more than you need unless you decide to start crafting other projects or breast forms. The microbeads are the trickiest part about making the breast forms and will easily drive you nuts as they float all over your work area.  I suggest trying to fill the fabric covers outside.  Leave as small an opening as possible to fill the beads so you can contain them better and have less whipstitching to do after the covers are full of microbeads.  Also make sure the fabric covers are a tight weave and won't let the tiny beads push out. Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2013 12:42PM - edited Jul 2, 2013 01:15PM by LindaLou53 Comparison of Blood Pressure Measured at the Arm, Ankle and Calf http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19032301 Generally, BP readings taken in the leg will be higher than those in the arm.  Discomfort is less in the ankle than the calf so ankle BP may be preferred.  I still continue to use wrist BP readings for all my medical office visits.  Hopefully, there will one day be a non-invasive method for taking BP that will better minimize LE risk while also avoiding potential complications related to leg BPs. Below is a very detailed medical article studying NON-INVASIVE continuous monitoring of BP (mean blood pressure), HR (heart rate), CO (cardiac output), and SV (cardiac stroke volume).  The Nexfin finger cuff system referred to in this study is currently designed for professional use in diagnostic, outpatient, inpatient and acute care settings.  If this technology becomes more widely available and accepted for its accuracy, I suspect it may ultimately be followed by a more compact and portable consumer based product. Noninvasive continuous hemodynamic monitoring http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3391359/ Nexfin http://www.bmeye.com/products/products-nexfin/products-nexfin-features There are a few basic finger cuff blood pressure units available now for consumer purchase but I am not aware of their brand/feature set or reliability.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 01:27PM - edited Jan 5, 2011 01:48PM by LindaLou53 Yes, we are all anatomically unique and our number of nodes will vary based on that uniqueness in addition to the degree of surgical removal the surgeon opts to use. Here is a fairly comprehensive article on Axillary Lymph Nodes found on the Ganfyd site which is similar to Wikipedia but is specifically a free medical knowledge base and collaborative medical reference by medical professionals and invited non-medical experts. www.ganfyd.org/index.php?title... The interesting point is that from a strictly anatomical classification they list 6 separate classifications of axillary nodes.  From the surgical viewpoint as it relates to breast cancer surgery, however, they define nodal locations by the term "station"  or  "level" of nodes.  So surgically they refer to 3 levels of axillary nodes.  Most Sentinel Node biopsies include just those nodes that light up first from the injected dye and possibly any surrounding or suspicious looking nodes in that area.  Typically a sentinel node will be in the Level 1 area of the axilla but not always....again we are all different and the pattern of lymphatic flow will vary in individuals. In recent years the term "axillary dissection"  is vaguely defined to mean the removal of level 1 and 2 nodes or even just level 1 nodes.  It is really up to the discretion of the surgeon.  Level 3 nodes typically are not removed unless there is known pathology and evidence of very locally advanced disease. We must remember that our entire bodies are covered by lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes.  Axillary nodes are only one component of our entire lymphatic system.  Even in the case of breast cancer, we have nodes that are considered surgically inoperable because of their location.  These would include the intramammary nodes that can be very near or underneath the breast bone making biopsy and removal difficult if not impossible. So when it comes to the difference in the nodal counts that we hear reported it can be a factor of how many levels of nodes were removed in addition to the normal anatomical variations between each of us. I had 23 nodes removed which included my level 3 nodes.  All 23 were found to be positive so my onc and I made the assumption than any nodes left behind were also positive. We have been aggressive in treatments though and are thrilled to be past my 5 year mark still NED!  Just remember ladies that positive nodes means a well functioning lymphatic and immune system doing its job, capturing and imprisoning those cancer cells that are trying to move out of the breast area.  I know we would all rather not have any nodes positive.....but we also know 0 nodes is no quarantee that cancer cannot still spread in other ways.  We have heard the story too often of Stage 1 ladies with 0 nodes ending up Stage IV. I say hurray for a strong lymphatic system and know that our future prognosis is not always "told by the nodes". Hang in there ladies!

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 06:58PM LindaLou53 wrote: I am still in the process of taking twice a day measurements of both my arms while wearing the ArmCare sleeve but thought I would make a few comments today about the SilverWave garment.  I was interested in trying it out just to see the fit and whether or not I could find a way to use it along with my other compression garments.  My thinking was I knew it would not provide enough compression for my left LE arm but wondered if the wave pattern might have an impact on my fibrotic areas in addition to providing some mild support to my right At-Risk arm.  As others have mentioned I found the garment to be very comfortable to wear.  I was a little suprised at the long wrist cuffs and "gathered" construction in the forearm area as Binney noted, however, found that the design seemed to fit my arm shape without any loose or too tight areas.    In spite of my long arms the sleeves fit comfortably and had plenty of stretch.  I did note that the band going across my back shoulders seemed a little loose but I definitely felt it was comfortable and no areas digging into my shoulders or axilla area.   I decided that in order to test the impact of the SilverWave fabric without compromising my needed compression levels for my LE arm, I would need to wear it underneath my current Mediven 550 Custom sleeve along with my Mediven 550 custom glove.  I did wear this combination as seen in the picture for a couple days.    It was comfortable, no unusual binding or irritations noted.  I did find that after removing the SilverWave garment I had a "roadmap"  of ridges left behind, similar to what I see after wearing my JoviPak nighttime garment. As others have mentioned, I found that my right Non-LE but at risk arm was more stimulated than usual with new sensations but that could be just the initial adjustment to wearing a garment.  I did not have any achyness or irritation noted on the right arm while wearing the SilverWave like I did when wearing the first ArmCare sleeve I tried. Because my current project is determining whether the Class II ArmCare sleeve can provide adequate compression, I stopped wearing the SilverWave for now and am strictly wearing the ArmCare during the day, sometimes alternating days with my regular Mediven sleeve.  I always wear my Medi glove no matter which sleeve I am wearing.  I am keeping track of circumference measurements twice a day at 6 points on each arm.  3 points below the elbow and 3 points above.  Now that I have replaced my original ArmCare sleeve with the non-defective black original version, I have been tracking my measurements for 9 days straight. I know Sue Callison was in Italy a week ago and hopefully she will have some news soon regarding garment revisions and future plans for expanding garment selections.  I will let both her and all of you know the results of my little experiment with the ArmCare Sleeve as soon as I feel I have enough data to share my opinion.

She also had a "complete pathological response" to the chemo but still followed up with lumpectomy and will now be starting radiation.  I just celebrated the 4 year anniversary last Saturday of my bilateral mastectomy w/o reconstruction, followed by chemo and rads for a Stage 3C ILC with 23 positive nodes and so far remain NED. Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2010 05:45PM LindaLou53 wrote: COOBIE BRA UPDATE: I am always a little hesitant about "one size fits all"  clothing but thought I would give the Coobie bra a try.  My black Coobie bra just arrived today and I have been wearing it for about 4 hours.  I inserted my TLC lightweight microbead forms (sz 8 on my right, sz 7 on my left) and so far it is pretty comfortable.  Here is my general impression along with some pics. (I'm a visual kind of person! ) 1.  The bra is of a very soft and stretchy 88% Nylon 12% Spandex knit.  2.  There are no rigid seams or bands 3.  There are no back clasps or hooks.  It is designed like a Sports bra that you have to pull on over your head and or step into like a swimsuit. 4.  It comes with small pads in the bra pockets that could be used as "enhancers" for someone with a lumpectomy or as additional padding with a prosthesis, or just removed completely.  I removed the pads in order to get my microbead forms to fit.  Being one size fits all, the bra cups are on the small side but are very stretchy.  I had to enlarge the opening into the bra pocket to insert my Sz 8 and Sz 7 forms more easily but once seated properly, the bra holds them firmly in place, no shifting around. 5.  The straps are very skinny, but soft and stretchy with adjustments in the front.  They can be completely removed and the bra comes with a set of clear transparent straps also. 6.  The band at the bottom of the bra is about 1 inch wide, soft, stretchy but fits snug enough that the bra does not ride up even with the lightweight forms.  I used to wear a 38C bra and this is not too tight on me, snug but not binding. 7.  The sides and back of the bra are all one piece of fabric, smooth and high cut so it fits high under the arms and also on the back. 8.  The neckline actually fits pretty snug to the chest and does not do much gapping to reveal scars or prosthesis.  Black colored bras tend to make gaps less noticeable though since it looks like a shadow instead of fabric showing under clothes. I was initially concerned that the bra pockets were too small for my forms but after getting them properly seated, the forms provide a decent projection in the profile view. My feelings are that this is certainly a bra worth trying.  It is NOT an expensive heavily constructed bra but that is why it is light, stretchy and comfortable.  If someone needs full support for an existing breast or heavy silicone forms I would be less enthusiastic that this is the bra for you.  This bra really provides no support as such.  It is more like going without a bra and just wearing a light stretchy tube top or sports bra without the added support.  BUT, for someone who is small busted or has had bilateral mx and wants to wear lightweight forms I think it is definitely worth looking into it. There will be some persons for whom the "one size fits all"  just won't work, but within the size range the bra is advertised at I think most people will find it comfortable. I plan on wearing mine for a few days and see if my opinion changes.  For now, I am more favorably impressed than I was expecting to be.  I still feel that this bra may not hold up as well as the heavier ones but it also is not as expensive as standard mastectomy bras.  It definitely has the comfort factor working for it over a heavy duty mastectomy bra. www.shopcoobie.com/ Here are some pics: Front of the Coobie Bra with the small cup pads removed:   Coobie Bra Back turned Inside Out:  Coobie Bra Cup Pocket:  Coobie Bra Profile and Neckline:   Coobie Bra Profile in Clothes:  Coobie Bra Front in Clothes:

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2010 07:41PM LindaLou53 wrote: ANOTHER COOBIE UPDATE: I agree with Anne that the Coobie bra is best suited for someone with bilateral mastectomy.  Because the fabric is so stretchy and non-supportive of any significant weight they probably won't work well with heavy prosthesis or mismatched real breast + prosthesis.   Bearing that in mind, I have to say that I have been wearing the coobie bra for a week now and find them very comfortable, non-binding, non-riding up and surprisingly light with the microbead forms.  I suspect one reason my microbeads project well in this bra is because the cups are small and force the larger microbead forms to push out more and not flatten as much because there is more density in the larger forms but without added weight. I just wanted to mention in case anyone else is considering these bras, that I found an Ebay seller who sells the Coobie bras at a discounted price ($6.99 each vs $20 each on the Coobie site).  I ordered the bras to see if they are the same as the one I ordered from the official Coobie site and they do appear to be the same bra with some minor differences.  The printing on the inside back band of the Ebay bras reports the fabric as 90% Nylon and 10% Spandex however both fabrics feel identical to me.  The style, shape and size of the bras is the same but the Ebay bra lists the style # as 6017 and the Coobie bra is # 9012.  Both are labeled as made in China.  One other minor difference is the Ebay bras have the straps attached with the adjustment side in the back instead of the front of the bra.  This is completely changeable though since the straps can be removed and attached so that the adjustment is in front. I ordered 3 of the Ebay Coobie bras and including shipping/handling the total was $30.97 which is quite a savings over the $20 Coobie bras.  With this particular Ebay seller the shipping for the first bra is $5.50 but each additional bra is $2.50. (at least to my midwest zipcode...it may be different in other areas of the US.) Here is the link to the Ebay listing if anyone is interested: http://cgi.ebay.com/NEW-COOBIE-FREE-SIZE-SEAMLESS-BRAS-WHITE-BLACK-BEIGE-/120596953941?cmd=ViewItem&pt=US_CSA_WC_Intimates&var=&hash=item61ca584df7

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2007 11:00PM LindaLou53 wrote: I have found my chemo nurses to be the best for starting IV lines on me.  I have LE in my left arm and am at risk in my right.  They usually can get it with one stick so I always go to the chemo center first before my scans so they can put a catheter or heplock in.  The radiology staff is usually very relieved when I show up with a line already in place. Because of my LE risk I also make sure the radiology staff adjusts the Contrast infusion rate to a lower setting so it does not risk damaging the blood vessel. They tell me there is a range of pressure settings that can be used and still be effective for the scans.  I just notice a longer "hot flush sensation" when they deliver the contrast at a slower rate.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2008 04:30PM LindaLou53 wrote: I took Xeloda along with my Taxotere chemo for 6 rounds over 4 months.  Started out at 3000mg per day, 14 days on / 7 days off.  At start of the 3rd round I developed severe hand/foot syndrome and lymphedema of my affected arm at the same time.  I was definitely at risk for LE due to 23 nodes removed, all positive, lots of cording and scarring on my surgical side, but I do believe the additional inflammation caused by the hand/foot syndrome may be what pushed me over the edge. It is very important that if you start to get any redness, pain or swelling in your hands/feet that you notify your onc right away.  Don't be a hero and try to tough it out.  Dosage adjustment can make a big difference in reducing the inflammation and possibly prevent more serious complications. Regarding the Vit B6....it is actually recommended by many oncs for patients on Xeloda to also take at least 200 - 400mg of Vit B6 every day.  Theory is it may help protect the nervous system and reduce onset of hand/foot. Xeloda is a very effective chemo drug that can produce dramatic improvement in tumor markers and mass size.  My onc also had me take 500mg Xeloda every single day of my radiation treatments because it is supposed to help sensitize the tumors for better response to radiation. I never really had any other major side effects like nausea or diarrhea with the Xeloda....just the hand/foot and that got better when I switched to 7days on/ 7 days off.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 03:12PM LindaLou53 wrote: Kate:  I'm so happy the bras are working for you!  I'm also glad to hear that you are doing and feeling so well one month post BMX....that is fantastic!  You still need to take it easy when it comes to lifting and returning to your normal work load.  Post operative healing takes many months so treat your body gently!  I totally agree that for some of us reconstruction is just not that enticing.  I have never regretted my decision and find it actually affords so many more options.  I go flat anytime I like at home or at the gym or shopping etc., but I still have a huge variety of choices for bras, camisoles, sports tops and prosthesis whenever I feel like "dressing up"  or just need a piece of clothing to fit better. I really am having a ton of fun with the new Coobie bras and lightweight microbead forms. I just experimented yesterday with laundring a Coobie bra with the microbead forms still in the pockets.  I threw them in cold water on the gentle cycle and then gentle fluff dry for about 30 minutes.  They came out great!  The microbead forms still felt slightly damp but were plumped up and not damaged in anyway I could tell.  I just let them air dry in the sunshine the rest of the way.  The Coobie bra helped protect the forms and it saved me the trouble of having to remove and re-insert the forms each time.  I did remove the little elastic straps on the bras though before throwing them in the wash.  I was afraid they might be a tangled mess if I didn't.  You could also throw the bras and forms in a regular netted laundry bag too to keep them separate from the rest of the laundry. Patty:  So glad you found the Coobies now before your surgery!  That will give you a nice option for the tender healing period when you wouldn't want anything heavy on your chest anyway.  Be sure to check out the TLC lightweight microbead forms to use with the bras.  There are many of us now wearing some version of those forms and loving them even years out after surgery! Best wishes for your upcoming surgery and be sure to let us know how you are doing.
